text:
Good and easy! I didn't have any Root Beer, so I used Pepsi. I used a pork shoulder and rubbed it down with some salt, pepper and garlic. I poured 1 can of Pepsi over the top. It was not enough to cover it (don't know if that makes a difference or not). I was home, so I flipped it halfway through cooking. I cooked it on low for about 7 hours. Once I drained the Pepsi out, I added some BBQ sauce and let it cook for another 30 minutes or so. It was very moist...not dry at all. I definitely prefer smoked pulled pork, but this is a great substitute (and half the effort).

text:
This was definitely a winner! I did make a couple of changes. I used a boneless pork roast. I made a rub of sea salt, pepper, onion powder and garlic powder that I applied liberally to the pork roast and I marinated it in root beer over night in the fridge. In the morning I took it out of the fridge, let it come to room temperature, poured more root beer in the crock pot (just to cover the meat entirely) and then put it on low.  Served it on lightly toasted potato bread rolls.  Very good!

userID:
5040973
Display Name:
Kenzie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/433199.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved this and so did I. So easy to make and such a flavorful dish. I switched to a less expensive meat under the adivce of previous reviews, using the Boston butt instead. The smallest at the grocery store at the time was 5.87lbs, so I had to use more ingredients. About 2/3 of a 2 liter bottle of A&W root beer (enough to almost completely submerge the meat in my slow cooker) and 2 bottles of Sweet Baby Ray's barbeque sauce [Sweet & Spicy, Hickory & Brown Sugar (18 fl oz each)]. Before placing in the slow cooker on low for 10 and 1/2 hours (I prepped this before bed), I trimmed the fat and pricked the meat (for absorbing some of the flavors and releasing some fat), rubbing a mixture of a tablespoon each of the following: cumin, onion powder, garlic powder, cayenne pepper, chili powder, black pepper, paprika, and salt. After draining, I shredded the pork, added the sauces, and returned to the slow cooker for another hour. Perfect. Served on warm buns to an eager family on Independence Day!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe.  I added an sliced onion to the crockpot when I began cooking.  Just a preference of mine.  I've cooked pork in colas before, but the root beer was something new and I had it on hand so thought I'd try it.  To those expecting some flavor from it that were disappointed, I think the carbonated drinks have more of a tendency to affect the tenderness of the meat rather than add flavor.  It came out very good.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's barbecue sauce (my favorite) and it was delicious.  I don't think there is much difference between using root beer or some type of cola.  Tasted the same.  I agree that using a pork tenderloin for this dish is a waste of money.  Buy a cheap cut!!!  That's what the slow cooker is for.

text:
MMMmm!!  I used 2-lb. Boston butt with a bone in, like another reviewer suggested, as it's cheaper. The cut has just the right amount of fat in it.

I found that I had to add another bottle of A&W root beer to bring the liquid level up (my crock pot is gigantic). I turned the pork over a few times, and it was completely falling apart after 5.5 hours.

After draining the rootbeer, I topped it with local Climax moppin' and soppin' sauce (which I was initially apprehensive about). So juicy, tender and delicious!!

text:
This message is for the person who cooked a 6 pound pork roast in six hours but the recipe didn't turn out.  Instead of cooking the roast too long, it sounds like it wasn't cooked long enough.  I cooked a 2.5 pound tenderloin for six hours and it was tender and delicious.  If you use a larger piece of meat, you will need to cook it longer.  Six pounds will probably take at least 12 hours to cook.  Also, make sure that you increase the rest of the ingredients.

This was amazing! I am not a big fan of BBQ, but my family is, so I decided to make it. I used a can and a half of pepsi to three pounds of pork shoulder. I cooked on low around 5-6 hours. city:

None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE pulled pork- so the results were still more than edible. However, number 1- the smell of root beer in the slow cooker all day was honestly nauseating and number 2) there are just other simpler ways of cooking pull pork and get equally good or better results- i.e. using beef broth, real beer, onion soup mix, etc. If determined to use the root beer I think I would recommend using less of it and some of another broth or liquid in place of the rest. AND definitely use the boston butt/pork shoulder- you can dig out the meatier places but the flavor the bone and fat provide while cooking are unparalleled by other cuts- although I am sure the pork tenderloin is also delicious- this is slow cooked pork pulled pork!

YUMMY!! I didn't use the pork tenderloin as recommended,  I used a pork shoulder instead, which was way more economical.
I also browned all four sides with olive oil, fresh garlic, salt, and pepper before I put it in the crock pot. 
I also added liquid smoke in with the root boor and I walked away until I added the bbq sauce the last hour and a half. 
The meat just fell apart and was so juicy and delicious. A great recipe when it's too cold to use the smoker and you're craving pulled pork.

text:
This is THE absolute best recipe for pulled pork. I tweaked it just a bit and rubbed the pork with  black pepper, crushed garlic, dry mustard & onion powder before hitting the root beer. We have passed this recipe on to quite a few of our friends & neighbors and they absolutely love it. I use Sprecher root beer (imho the best root beer around), & Bone Suckin Sauce Hot/Thicker Style (by far the best BBQ sauce ever!). Thank you so much for letting the world know about this great sandwich. Oh definitely using onion kaiser rolls, colby jack or pepper jack cheese & cole slaw on it is our favorite preparation! I did make this once and it came out kind of dry after 8 hours, so the 2nd time I only cooked it for 6 hours and it was perfect!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome and super-easy!!  I used pork tenderloin (I prefer very lean meat, so I use pork tenderloin in all my slow cooker recipes) and a 21.6-oz bottle of BBQ Sauce (instead of the recommended 18-oz. listed in the original recipe).  Cooked the roast for 7-1/2 hours, then for another 30 minutes after shredded the pork and stirring in the BBQ sauce (so, total of 8 hours of cooking time).  Turned out to be delicious!  Lean, moist, easily-shredded....perfect!!  I wouldn't limit sauce to only 18 oz, as called for in the recipe.  I think it would be too dry without the extra few ounces I added by using a 21.6-oz bottle.  You could even add 2 or 3 more ounces and I don't think it would be too moist.  21.6-oz seemed perfect to me.  I used Hunts Original BBQ Sauce, but any BBQ sauce will work nicely in this I think.     I'll be making this again.

text:
I would give this 10 stars if I could.  This was delicious!!!  I used the butt portion of meat and did what one other person mentioned and placed a dry rub of onion soup mix, garlic, steakhouse seasoning and worchestire sauce.  Threw it in the crock pot and added one can of A&W Root Beer.  Cooked on low for 7 hours.  I then poured out the Root Beer.  Pulled the meat off the bone with a fork and disgarded the fatty pieces.  I then added barbecue sauce and cooked for another 30 minutes.  Hubby loved it, and my 8 year old asked for more and even the dog and cat got a few nibbles.  Moi Delicious!!!  Oh yes and I also made Mom's Coleslaw recipe from this site.   It was the perfect coleslaw to compliment this dish.  Will absolutely make this one again.

text:
I also took the advice of others and used a 4 pound shoulder instead of the tenderloin.  I  doubled the root beer and the barbeque sauce because I doubled the size of the pork.  For sauce - I used one bottle of Bulls eye hickory and one bottle of the sweet and tangy to balance each other out.  When it was done, I removed the pork and pulled it into shreds with two forks, drained all of the liquid and returned the pork to the slow cooker and mixed in the barbeque sauce and let it go for another hour to let the sauce soak in.  It was so good.  I am definitely going to do this one again.

text:
I was AMAZED at how wonderful and easy this recipe was. I bought a 3 pound pork loin for $6 and some change from a nice grocery store. I think it is definetly worth buying the leaner cut to save on fat because it is still moist & delicious. I followed all the steps exactly on here & I wouldn't change a thing. I used Sweet Baby Ray's award winning BBQ sauce & there did not have to be any additional seasonings like garlic powder or S&P. I cooked the pork for 6 hrs on low, drained it, shredded it, and cooked with the BBQ sauce for 1 hour. I served it on potato buns as is. I will be making this often, and I think it would be great for sliders for appetizers on the mini Kings Hawaiian Rolls.

text:
I made for my company summer kick off luncheon for 40 people mostly men who work outside. Use 30# of pork shoulder which I pre-rubbed with dark brown sugar, yellow mustard, minced garlic, onion powder, apple cider vinegar, worchershire sauce, salt and pepper. Placed in an 18 qt roaster @ 325 topped with 2 liters Mug Rootbeer and some bay leaves. Cooked for 7 hours. Cooled to shred and remove bones and extra fat, tossed the juiced because of the fat content. Reheated next day w/1 bottle of zesty chili sauce, apple juice and water to cover. Reheated @ 250 for 1 hour. Most employees skipped the barbecue sauce, loving the flavor as it was. Will be keeping this one handy. Thank you.

text:
This is the only way I can eat pork BBQ now. I've had gastric bypass, and most bbq is WAY too fatty for me to eat. Using a tenderloin cut, with diet root beer, makes this a delicious meal for me and my family. I rub the tenderloin with fresh ground pepper, some garlic powder (or add in some fresh pressed garlic in the crock pot), and cover with root beer. I serve on buns, topped with cole slaw. This has been a hit with family, friends, and the men in my hubby's squadron. I get asked to make this again and again!

text:
This was easy and tasty-what more can you ask for? I used a 4 lb pork loin roast that had just a little fat on it, seasoned the meat beforehand -  which I definitely recommend, and added about 24 ounces of root beer.  After meat was tender and pulled apart, I drained the root beer off and added a full bottle of Stubbs BBQ sauce.   My husband and kids loved it, and I loved how simple it was. Note: As others have mentioned, for a simple clean-up, be sure to spray your crock put with Pam beforehand.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such a great and easy way to make “barbecue” at home. I am a native Memphian, and we are picky about these kinds of things. I used a premium brand of root beer (Hansens), which I think probably contributed to the great taste. Based on the other reviews, I did salt and pepper and pierce the pork before putting it in the slow cooker. I also covered the meat entirely with root beer, which is probably more liquid-to-meat than the normal technique but definitely necessary for this recipe. I did use pork tenderloin, too, because that is what I had in my freezer. Several people noted that this is an expensive cute of meat to shred, but it is also very lean. Considering that there is sugar in the root beer and in most barbecue sauces, cutting the fat helps the nutrition of this recipe. Also, sometimes pork tenderloin goes way on sale, and this is a great way to use some out of your freezer.

text:
This recipe was SO EASY and SO GOOD.  I used a 4 lb shoulder cut, trimmed the fat, seasoned with garlic powder and pepper and cooked it in the slow cooker in the root beer on low for about 9 hours.  I used enough root beer to almost cover the meat and turned the meat half way through the cook time.  Drained the root beer and mixed in the Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and let it "get happy" with the BBQ sauce until warmed through.  Served on Garlic french bread rolls "southern style" with cole slaw on top and my family and friends devoured the entire roast and begged for more.  AWESOME recipe!!  Will be making this again and again. Thanks so much!!

text:
Update 3/2011 - Tenderloin makes a BIG difference. I season my meat with Montreal Steak seasoning and soak overnight in coke. Then add the BBQ sauce with approx 2 hours to go.  FABULOUS!!!  

Really a 3.5.  My husband LOVED this recipe and would have rated it a 5; however, I thought it was "just ok."  Not fantastic - as I was expecting, given all the rave reviews. I seasoned my meat and let it stand overnight - and even with that, the meat was just ok. I agree with another user who said they don't see evidence of what the rootbeer is for. Based on the reviews, I also used pork shoulder, instead of tenderloin and I found this meat to be very fatty. My family and I were picking out "nasty pieces" throughout the entire meal. To each his own - but I certainly don't think the price savings justified the unappealing nature of the cheaper meat. I think I will try this recipe again with tenderloin and see if it turns out any better. I definitely think the BBQ sauce should be added to the meat much sooner than called for.

text:
I'm not a slow cooker type of person.  I don't like my meats cooked for long hours because they usually dry out.  I was VERY impressed with this recipe!  I had borrowed my sisters slow cooker for some refried beans and decided to try another recipe since I had it here.  This was wonderful!  I have celiac disease and have to watch my gluten so I don't usually have root beer on hand as most is not gluten free.  So I substituted Dr Pepper instead. I also used pork butt instead of a loin. This was so good I would proudly serve this to company.  Thank you for giving me my first real slow cooker meal recipe and for converting me to using one.  Great, great recipe.

text:
This was pretty good. My family was not totally blown away, but it was quick and easy. I dont know if I would use the root beer again or not because I have made this before using the McCormick pulled pork seasoning packets and it turned out a little more flavorfull. I used sweet baby rays bbq and added a little after the first 3-4 hours of cooking. I drained out the rootbeer and added the rest of the bbq and cooked for another 45 min. I also cooked it on high for about 5 hours. All crockpots are different - mine is a newer one so I was hoping it would cook a little faster then 5 hours, but no such luck. If you are looking for a very easy pulled pork and not a whole lot of seasoning then this one is for sure worth trying.

text:
had this in my MIL's house and it was great, so I am trying it myself tonight.  Also used the pork shoulder for the low cost aspect.  TIP TO CLEAN YOUR SLOW COOKER:  if you are having a hard time getting cooked on food off it, soak a dryer sheet in it for a few hours and everything should come right up.  Fill with water enough to cover all stuck on food and it will wipe up after a few hours.  Works everytime!!

text:
I wanted to make pulled pork for a July 4th BBQ.  My husband told me I would need a smoker.  Not really having the room for(or funds to buy) a smoker, I came to Allrecipes looking for something I could make with my crockpot. Saw this recipe and had to try it.  I used pork butt, Barq's and seasoned the meat with salt & pepper.  Bought some sauce from a local BBQ joint and served it on slider rolls.  It was heaven!  The best part is that it seems as if you slaved over it for hours, but really it doesn't take much effort at all (especially if your husband does the pulling);).  You should keep in mind that the pork will cook down.  I bought 5lbs of pork for 20 people.  We only had about 13 and there was only a tiny bit of it left after the party.  I made this again last night, cause I didn't get enough on the 4th!  Can't wait until tonight's dinner!

text:
This recipe would be 5 stars but I had to add to it to make it 5 stars. The first time I made it I followed the recipe exactly- it was ok not great but ok. It definitely was sweet but I like me bbq pork sweet and spicy. So, the second time I made it I made a dry rub with brown sugar, chili powder, cumin, garlic powder and red pepper flakes. I caked the pork butt with the dry rub and then cooked it in the slow cooker with the rootbeer. We used sweet baby rays sweet and spicy bbq sauce and when we added the bbq sauce we added chopped jalepeno peppers. It was awesome!!

text:
These were great but I don't think the root beer played too big a part in the taste.  The BBQ sauce makes all the difference.  We used Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory & Brown Sugar BBQ Sauce.  If you don't have rootbeer I wouldn't worry, you could use any other dark soda or even just water as long as you have lots of sauce.  Also, we seasoned the meat with Johnny's and Garlic salt/powder through out the day.  This is great served with frozen fries or a green salad.

text:
I made this with pork shoulder and Pepsi because that's what I had.  I seasoned the meat with salt and pepper, put a layer of sliced onions on the bottom of the crock pot, poured the Pepsi and added about 1/4 cup of barbeque sauce.  Once it was done, I shredded the meat, discarded the onions and liquid and poured the rest of the barbeque sauce into the crock pot.   It was delicious.

text:
I get so many compliments on this pulled pork.  But... I change it a bit to make it my own.  I add the rootbeer and the BBQ sauce in the slow cooker.  I add 1/4 tsp of smoke flavor and also add 1/4 tsp cumin and 1/2 tsp of garlic powder and onion powder.  Cook on low for 8 hours.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe. Made this several times now. use pork shoulder. the blade cut is tender. have used several brands of root beer. found the more flavorful the root beer the more interesting the meat. have tried it with hard root beer. Not much different. I have experimented with variety of rubs. usually something on sale. get 7-9 lbs piece, rub it and leave it a minimum of 45 minutes before cooking. place into 6 qt cooker, add 12oz root beer and cook on low 7-9 hours depending on weight. when done, reserve 1 cup liquid, skimming off fat. combine with bottle of BBQ sauce and cook down to desired thickness.

Very good ! Our church co-operates with other churches in Bethlehem in running a homeless mens and womens shelter throughout the winter months. One of the church memebers donated a 10 pound pork loin for us to cook pulled pork sandwiches for close to 30 homeless men. I cut it into quarters and used this amazingingly easy recipe to cook the meat. The pork loin pulled apart very easily then I used Sweet baby Rays honey barbrque sauct to finish it up. We served the sandwiches with string beans and applesauce plus many home baked desserts. The guys really enjoyed it !!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was incredible.  I used A&W rootbeer, and two pork roasts since I could fit two in my crock pot. Covered with the soda and nothing else. Cooked on low for about 8 hours. The meat had a pretty good taste. After it cooled I drained the rootbeer and pulled the pork apart. I then mixed in about 1/4 cup of liquid smoke and some garlic powder. I let set in the fridge overnight and put back on low. After the meat was warmed I added two bottles of Sweet Baby Ray's sauce. I gave it a little taste and wasn't all that impressed. I usually use KC Masterpiece. I let the flavors marry for a couple of hours on low and Wow!!!! what a happy marriage it was.  The sauce and the pork came together in a fantastic taste explosion.  It was the best I have ever tasted.  Big hit with the family, even my daughter who hates bbq sauce on pulled pork, loved it. Try this recipe and you won't be sorry.

text:
This was my first time making pulled pork on my own, and I was specifically looking for a tenderloin recipe because I personally did not want to deal with all of the fat on less lean pieces of meat! Worth it - I only spent $10 total on 2 1.5lb pork loins from my grocery store. I was skeptical - but in no way did this recipe taste like rootbeer after draining the liquid. The only thing I did different was cover the bottom and sides of the pork in the crockpot with a sliced yellow onion and a sprinkle of garlic powder. I used Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce and served with a thinly sliced red onion and toasted sesame buns! Will definitely be making this again!

text:
I did what the recipe called for, except I used almost a full 2liter of rootbeer. I put the pork tenderloin and rootbeer in the crockpot around 2:00pm (I made sure the tenderloin was completely submerged) set the crockpot on low and set the timer for 6 hours. When it had 40 mins left on the timer I took it out, drained the rootbeer, cleaned my crockpot, put the tenderloin back in the crockpot and then added BBQ sauce and let it warm back up on the "keep warm" setting for the last 40 mins. Absolutely delicious!! My boyfriend took a bite and the first words out of his mouth after he took his bite were "mmmm, this is definitely a do-over".

text:
I recommend making this with ~ 3lb pork shoulder instead of the recommended tenderloin. I used a 2lb one, and the meat to sauce ratio was not quite right. I didn't read the directions and added the BBQ sauce and root beer at the beginning, as well as a bit (about 2-3Tbsp) of white vinegar, to cut some sweetness. It turned out well. No need to drain this recipe, which was good. I served it on buns with crunchy fried onions, which made a nice contrast in texture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe for feeding 6-8 people in a pinch!
I work on the mountains during the day, and this recipe allows me to throw something delicious quickly in the slow-cooker (making the home smell savory when I arrive back:) before heading out the door!
Its ready to go the second I walk in the door: I simply put it in a oven-safe casserole dish, pull it apart as directed and let it bake in the barbecue sauce of choice (taste preference of heat/spicy level dependent on guests) at about 325 degrees for about 15-20min or until bubbly (Note: I live at altitude).
Add a starch, and green side [on this plate, featured with sprouts and mini-multi-colored taters] and a few extra condiments for your guests' liking/ what's on hand.....and your in business with this awesome go-to slow-cooker pulled pork!

text:
Great recipe though I agree it could have used way less liquid broth from the start as the pork ends up releasing it's own liquid which results in a diluted tasting sauce. I use powder/dried seasoning/chicken flavoring (Maggy cubes) and would suggest mixing this straight into the BBQ sauce in the crockpot, omitting the extra liquid.

text:
I used Pork chops for this recipe.  I placed 500ml of cider in slow cooker with them along with 1 large onion chopped, 3 cloves of garlic and salt and pepper.  once the pork was cooked i took the liquid and veg out, liquidized them and having pulled the pork apart i soaked it in the now blitzed liquid.  I later drained most of the liquid off before adding the bbq sauce and placing the pork back in heat for service.  Superb flavour from the apple adding a lovely sweetness to the meat, highly recommended.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a combination of pork tenderloin and boneless pork loin which I had in the freezer, and diet root beer (what I had on hand). I actually liked the pork loin (which I bought on sale for $1.99/lb) better than the tenderloin.  I also liked that when shredding, I didn’t have to go through the meat and discard all the fat that you have when using the typical Boston butt roast.  The meat cooked perfectly at 6 hours, and its flavor was fantastic, just an interesting little bit of sweetness from the root beer.  As other reviewers have mentioned, the BBQ sauce that you use will totally dominate the flavor of the pork, so at a minimum, choose one that you REALLY like.  Unfortunately, I wanted that pork flavor on my sandwich, and in the future, I will not use a powerful tomato-based BBQ sauce for this recipe.  I will serve the pork on its own, maybe wrapped in a lettuce leaf with some Asian garnishes, set some aside for some Mexican dishes, or try a vinegary North Carolina BBQ sauce for sandwiches.  And seriously, put meat in pot, add root beer, lid on, cook for 6 hours, shred, and add sauce...come on, it just doesn’t get much easier than that.  I’m not a huge crock pot fan, but this is one that I really enjoyed, and I’m not alone, with 2,833 reviews at 4.5 stars.  A winner, for sure!

text:
I've made this recipe about a dozen times now and I just love how simple it is! All you need are 3 ingredients! I've made it with tenderloin or pork shoulder, whichever is on sale. I prefer to use Dr. Pepper, but it's good with root beer as well.. just a lot sweeter. Any dark regular soda will do. It's the carbonation that really tenderizes the meat. After cooking on low for 10 hours, I drain the soda, add a bottle of Sweet Baby Rays Sweet & Spicy sauce, and cook on low for another hour. This recipe is so simple and so good. I always get requests for this one.

text:
Good, but it's very much just the sauce on the meat that you taste in the end. Unfortunately, I went with a sweeter BBQ sauce and ended up with what tasted like a sloppy joe.  If I'd used a traditional sauce, though, I'd say the experience of the pulled pork would have been more on the mark.  I followed the directions, using a small pork shoulder with an average amount of fat on it, added sliced onion on the bottom. Used enough A&W root beer to come up to 3/4 of the side of the meat, cooked it for 8 hours on low, turned it about three times,dumped the juice/root beer/onions, added the BBQ sauce and cooked the last hour on high. I tasted the pork on it's own after shredding and sadly, honestly, the meat didn't taste like anything at all! Super-tender and shredded easily, obviously, but it had no real flavor. The meat wasn't supposed to be seasoned, so I was hoping for a rich flavor or something from just the root beer, but no.
**UPDATE: the root beer is meant to act as a tenderizer only and is not used for flavoring, according to a review I just read! That explains a lot!** Super-easy recipe and fairly cheap. I'll make it again, but just use a vinegar-based BBQ sauce next time.
But we did really like it and both ate two sandwiches!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pulled pork BBQ is a favorite of mine and cooking it in root beer really does make for tender, delicious meat. For me, this is a great, simple 4-star recipe that I'm able to make 5-star with a couple easy alterations. 

When I put the pork loin in my slow cooker, I dice up a large, sweet onion and press the pieces onto the top of the pork loin. I then sprinkle a couple tablespoons of sugar and a modest amount of cayenne pepper on top of the onions. The sugar allows the onions to caramelize and the onions and spice make for perfect, savory pulled pork that's flavorful even without sauce, if you'd like! I do like my sauce though and prefer to use a bottle of my favorite Carolina sauce or Sweet Baby Ray's, depending on my mood.

I serve this BBQ on top of a slice of gluten-free bread.

text:
I served this for a 'Grads and Dads' event a couple of weeks ago. Instead of tenderloin, I used pork shoulder purchased from Costco. If you haven't purchased it there previously, start now. It was a spectacular piece of pork; much less fat than what you get at the grocery store. I assumed about 4 lbs of shoulder to substitute for 2 lbs of tenderloin. Otherwise, I used the recipe as stated, and thoroughly drained the fat when cooking was complete. I had to do one in the crock pot and the other in the oven. No difference except how long it took (oven was faster). Then I used bottled BBQ sauce (Kraft... was on sale). I got raves from my guests. I froze the leftovers in baggies and took one of the bags on our boat trip for July 4th. The encore performance was also easy and wonderful.

country:
None
text:
My husband, who owns a restaurant, said this is the best pulled pork he has ever tasted. I used a pork shoulder, filled the cooker with root beer until it covered about 1/3 of the meat and cooked on high for about 4 hours. I turned it to low to cook for another 5 hours. I drained the RB and took the meat out which fell apart so easily. I put the now pulled pork back in the cooker and mixed in a bottle of A1 steak sauce and half a bottle of Bulls Eye hickory smoke BBQ sauce (although anything smokey would give it that flavor.) I stayed away from honey based BBQ sauces, since the Root Beer is already sweet.  I let it cook on low in the sauce for about an hour.  I wouldn't recommend playing around with it. Just get a sauce (or sauce combo) that you like.

text:
I was really hesitant about this recipe at first (root beer?!) but I decided to try it out because of the rave reviews. Huge hit! I'm a picky eater, one of our guests is a picky eater, and we have 5 young girls that are all picky eaters and this stuff was devoured. I doubled the poundage of the recipe but used a pork shoulder which is much less expensive. Cooked skin on (in case anyone else is confused by that. I wasn't sure if I should leave it on or not. Leave it on, remove after cooking before shredding) and it took only about 6 hours (but my slow cooker runs high). Admittedly I thought I had made a terrible mistake making this recipe to entertain friends with by the smell. It wasn't awful but a very interesting odor (it is pork cooking in root beer, after all). But once I got it drained, shredded, and the BBQ sauce on it (we used our favorite: Garland Jack's Secret Six Original) all our mouths were watering. I put it back in the slow cooker for an hour on low with the BBQ sauce and served with Restaurant-Style Coleslaw I on top; though I omitted the onions from the recipe in favor of thinly sliced onions as an additional optional topping. It was so good my husband requested it for Father's Day.

Best shredded pork I ever had! I opted out of using pork tenderloin and instead got a nice pork loin way cheaper. Ended up using one liter of mug root beer but because crockpot was large and oval I topped it off with 2 cans of pepsi. I also sliced some onion and placed them underneath the meat for added flavor. This was an OK way to cook a 4 lb pork loin that I wanted to cook without turning on the oven or any fuss. I didn't think the root beer added any real flavor. I thought it was a bit dry, but with the BBQ sauce on it, the sandwiches were fine. I kept some of the meat out before adding BBQ sauce and made quesadillas the next night. I added chili powder, onion powder and cumin to the meat, and they turned out great.

text:
It can't get any easier than this. GREAT for beginners, people with busy schedules, people on a budget, its so simple and comes out tasting great! The first time I tried this I threw all the ingredients in (pork, rootbeer and bbq suace!) After cooking for about 7-9 hours, I shredded the meat while it was still in the pot, I also found that the sauce was too watery! (no way was I going to drain it- I already had the bbq sauce in it) If this happens to you, All you do is a add a dash or 2 of some CORNSTARCH stir it up and let that baby cook for an hour or until you see that the sauce has thicken and is of the perfect consistency. Yes I skipped a couple steps from the original recipe but it totally saved my dish and I made it that much easier.

AMAZING!!! I love this recipe and my fiancé can say the same!! I've tried A LOT of pulled pork recipes and hated every one of them but this one is to die for and so easy. My family is from Texas so we love our BBQ and this recipe makes us feel right at home right from our kitchen table in California :) We started out using hamburger buns for a pulled pork sandwich but this recipe comes with a lot of juice so the bun would get really soggy. After a few runs at it we decided to try it on sour dough bread because at the time it was the only bread in the house (I know... Weird!) But actually it was so good!!! The bread stayed nice and toasted and but we were still able to enjoy those wonderful juices! Y'all have to try this one!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tasted GREAT!

What I did:
Used a pork butt (Aprox 4 lbs)
Covered pork butt in crock pot with root beer and let cook for about 8 hours on low. (Flipping it halfway through).
My pork had a large piece of fat on it that I removed approximately at the 7 hour mark.
After about 8 hours, I took the pork out and shredded it in a bowl, removing any fatty pieces in the meat. 
The juice mixture was then poured from the crock pot, and the shredded meat back in. 
A small amount of root beer and a small portion of barbeque sauce were then added to taste and mixed in the crock pot. 
It then cooked for one last hour (at the 30 minute mark I stirred it.  
IT WAS SO GOOOOOOD!

The only thing I may have done differently is let it sit for another two hours, but thats it.

text:
I have NEVER made BBQ anything because you either get it right, or you don't. I found this recipe a few months ago, and I purchased a 7.5 pound pork shoulder on sale from Wegman's. ($1.29/pound). It sat in my freezer because I was scared to try it! (Note: I'm a city girl that is dating a country boy....so the pressure was definitely on!!) I decided to give it a whirl. I read through about 200 reviews and did tweak the recipe due to the fear of there not being any seasoning in the recipe....I used a pork shoulder, rubbed the meat with McCormick's Pulled Pork Seasoning and wrapped in saran wrap overnight, poured in anentire 2 liter bottle of Barq's Root Beet, and used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce. It was a HIT!! My boyfriend who is as country as country can be said this was the best he's ever had. Granted, he "had" to say that or he'd be sleeping on the couch! My 15 yr old son, however, is brutally honest when it comes to giving his opinion....and he gave it 2 thumbs up! YEAH!!!! The meat was very tender  (not mushy like some claimed)...it slid right off the bone when I drained the meat. This is a keeper...not just for the yumminess, but for the simplicity of the ingredients and the process in making it!! Thank you to the original poster for sharing this recipe!!

userID:
1444364
Display Name:
eryenne.ala

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Freakin' amazing. I made a few changes that others suggested, such as poking holes in the tenderloin first and then using a dry rub (garlic salt, onion powder, cayenne pepper, salt, pepper, etc.) before adding the root beer. It's cheaper to buy a 2L than a six-pack of 12oz bottles, anyway, so I just poured it in until it covered the pork (and I used closer to 3lbs). I cooked it on low for 10 hours, drained the root beer, then added more of the same spices to taste and most of a 40oz bottle of Jack Daniel's original BBQ sauce. I cooked it on low for another two hours, stirring often, and finished it off by slathering hamburger buns in margarine and throwing them under the broiler for a few minutes. Add some fresh green beans in lemon-butter sauce or corn on the cob, and you're golden! Accolades all around. Some of the best pulled pork I've ever had. :) AND SO EASY!

This was delicious and will definitely be a go to meal when I want to impress guests! I took the advice of many other reviewers and used pork shoulder and Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce...excellent recommendations. I also added onion and garlic to the slow cooker. If you're like me, and like a bit of spice, I recommend adding pureed chipotle in adobo sauce and adding it in the end with the bbq sauce.
I served the finished pulled pork with caramelised onions and baked potato.

text:
I received an advertisement in the mail to subscribe to All Reciepes magazine and saw this reciepe, tried it, mainly due to all the 5 star ratings.  As the saying goes "There's a reason that Baskin Robbins has 31 flavors."  Way, way too sweet; mushy meat.  Used Sweet Baby Ray's original sauce and pork shoulder. There are 2 people in my family who have real "sweet tooths" and they gave it a thumbs down.  The solution was to put salsa on it, to add flavor other than root beer and to cut the sweetness some. We followed the suggestion from AR people to use cole slaw on the sandwiches; it did help and because of that, we were able to eat it the first night.  To each his own. :)

For anyone in a hurry - this is a sure thing! We absolutely loved this easy recipe. text:
I used the butt as others mentioned. I've used this cut for other recipes in slow cooker and it works well. It is definately cheaper than tender loin and any flavor difference is minimal. The purpose of the root beer I'm not sure. I've done other pulled pork dishes that were just as good, thus the reason for 4 stars. It is good, but nothing special to other ways of preparing pulled pork. Much of the flavor of this recipe depends on the sauce you choose. I did add a lot of fresh garlic, as always. Made sliders with Amish Cole Slaw. It was a hit, but so was the way I've always prepared. Again, no differing value by adding root beer. The slow cooking is what makes it "melt in your mouth".

text:
Delicious! And so easy, even my boyfriend could do it! We used 1/2 of a 5.? pound shoulder roast (so 2.5+ pounds)and added salt, pepper, and garlic. I left the ingredients and the instructions with the boyfriend and went to work. After 6.5 hours it was not falling apart yet, so I turned it up to high for an hour. At 7.5+ hours it was shredable but could have cooked longer, but the kids were hungry so I drained it, shredded it and added the sauce. Most people cooked it in the sauce for another hour or more, but we didn't have time. Everyone loved it, even the picky 7-year-old! I had to stop the boyfriend from eating his third sandwich. I served it with Cole Porter Slaw from this site, which is awesome. Next time I will allow more cooking time, and maybe just use regular A&W instead of fancy local artisan root beer (the taste was a little overpowering). We will definitely make this again!

Display Name:
Leigh

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
TO DIE FOR! First time making pulled pork, I used tenderloin(long skinny kind) so I didnt have to deal with the fat..yes it may be a tiny bit drier to use in a crockpot but I really didnt notice or mind. It came out amazing! What happens is it will soak up the bbq sauce so make sure you account for that if you do use tenderloin. The fattier cuts prob wont soak it up as much. I did a dry rub of onion powder, s&p and let sit in freezer baggie in fridge all day. About 1030pm I cut each of the 2 tenderloins into sections so it would be easier to shred and wouldnt be long strings, jabbed them a few times w a knife and put into the cooker covered 3/4 of the way w A&W rootbeer turned on low. In the AM I drained, wiped down crock and let pork sit about 15 min before I shredded it, poured bottle of Sweet Baby Rays sweet n spicy (make sure to get this kind) and put whole thing cooker and all into fridge for the day. About noon I took it out, gave it a stir, this is when I noticed it sucked up most of the sauce so next time I will get bigger bottle..cooked on low for hour and half and OMG!!!! The flavor is just killer. It would be a tiny bit better only if it were a tad bit saucier but I did not feel like running out for more sauce.. other than that I would not change a thing! Def will make many more times thanks for the recipe..

text:
Fantastic and very easy to make! 

Some reviews say that Pork Shoulder is no different than the Pork Tenderloin... trust me, the Tenderloin makes a world of difference as does the BBQ Sauce. 

I also suggest that adding a chopped Onion from the start is a fantastic idea as well. I also add a half cup of Red Hot or sometimes a few dashes of Daves Insanity. Subsitute a nice Porter Beer in place of the Root Beer for a slightly different taste!

Just remember Tenderloin, Tenderloin, Tenderloin. Its worth the extra few bucks and a lot better cut, less fat and the 4 lbs you get instead of the 2 Loin is usually fat weight. The Shoulder leaves fat bits floating in your pulled pork no matter how much you trim it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe...very easy and tasty.  I may have solved the issue of the root beer taste.  I made two batches of this recipe using pork shoulders for a pot luck.  With the first shoulder, I put the pork in with the fat side down, added root beer about half way up the sides of the slow cooker and cooked on low for 8 hours.  The pork was tender and delicious but not falling off the bone.  When I cooked the second and much leaner shoulder, I placed it in the slow cooker with the fat side up, again adding root beer about half way.  The second shoulder was fall off the bone tender but there was a distinct root beer taste and the pork was way too sweet.  It seems having some fat melt into the liquid neutralizes the root beer flavor.  At least that way my experience.

text:
Mmmmm... I love this recipe. I currently have a batch cooking in my sow-cooker. The only variation I have for this is that I start to separate the pork slightly after approximately 4 hours to let the juices soak in. The reviewers who tasted rootbeer in the meat; did you drain, sauce and continue to cook for about one hour? if not, the rootbeer is still sitting on your meat and that's why you're tasting it!! There is a great "Bourbon Whiskey BBQ sauce" recipe on this site, which I am eager to try with this recipe. However, so far, using Kansas City Style Smokey BBQ sauce has been a total HIT. This is one of the best tasting pork barbeque sauces I've found so far and is kid-friendly.

I hate root beer. Let me reiterate. I absolutely despise root beer. But I found this recipe, had just bought a slow cooker, and my fiance loves pulled pork. So I tried it. I was stunned to taste it! It came out perfect! I stirred it a couple of times an hour, and seasoned it with salt and pepper beforehand. Perfection! Couldn't even taste the root beer with the barbeque sauce on!

city:

country:
None
text:
This was actually just simple and easy! I read over some of the recent reviews. The root beer worked better than water as far as the texture of the meat goes more than actually flavoring the meat. I had no issues with cleaning the root beer off of my crock pot, it actually came off with just water. My crock pot isn't anything fancy either, just an old hand-me-down one from a friend of mine who replaced hers a couple of Christmas' ago. Maybe that person didn't add enough root beer and/or over cooked it. Anyway, this was a great recipe. I work nights, so I just popped this baby in the crock pot with the root beer and cooked on low while I slept about 6 hours. When I woke up, I just drained the meat, shredded it, and topped it off with some sweet generic bbq sauce that I had in the fridge. =)

text:
OMG I'd give 10 stars if I could! I used a picnic shoulder cut.  Don't be afraid to use a cheaper cut because most of the fat cooks off & what is left comes off easily.  I covered the roast at least 1/2 way w/ rb, flipping it over the last couple of hours to make sure the whole thing was tender.  I cooked this over night all together about 11 hours. Lightly mixed 3/4 bottle bbq sauce & kept on warm for another hour to incorporate flavors. This was the most tender juicy pulled pork sandwich I ever had!!! Everyone loved this! I will definitly make again & maybe even for the next b-day party we have!  This is our new favorite recipe! Thanks for sharing.

text:
I have made this with pork tenderloin and cheaper cuts of pork. Personally, I like it either way equally, so I will go with cheaper cuts! While I have made it using root beer I have also made this with Cream Soda on a few occasions and beer every now and then with great success and wonderful flavor! So don't be afraid to change it up and use what you have. But for me, the key to a great pulled pork sandwich lies in the quality of the BBQ sauce. For the best you will ever put in your mouth, try Bourbon Whiskey BBQ Sauce from this site. It is off the charts delicious!

AWESOME!  I cooked two 8 lb. boston butt pork roasts in my slow cooker.  I cooked both for approximately 7 1/2 hours. I shredded and added sweet baby rays sauce.  I did save several ounces of juice from the slow cooker and added a small amount of liquid smoke to give it a "cheater" smoky flavor. the juice/liquid smoke mixture over top and it kept it moist.  I poured  I served it on mini Hawaiian rolls, yum!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good!  I did not do pork tenderloin, but had an almost 5 lb cut that was 6 grams fat/serving, which was in between the tenderloin and shoulder butt.  It was on sale for about $10.  I cut some onion and laid in on the bottom of the slow cooker bag.  Then put the pork on top and sprinkled with garlic powder, onion powder, pepper and seasoned salt, then covered the entire thing with root beer.  Flipped 3.5 hrs later and then about an hr before eatting, I drained bag and put in a new one.  I skimmed off the fat and then shredded and covered with Sweet Baby Rays bbq sauce.  Also added more seasoned salt, pepper and onion powder to taste.  5+ stars!!!  Made enough for 15+ sandwiches.

Fantastic recipe, but I do make a couple of changes! I put a dry rub on my roast that consist of brown sugar, Montreal chicken spice,and a little bit of fresh ground coffee. I leave it in the fridge for 4-6 hour or overnight works too. Then I sear the outside of te roast on my kamado BBQ, and then it goes in the slow cooker for 8hours with the root beer! My family LOVES it especially on gameday!

text:
The pork comes out moist and mouth-watering! So easy to pull!
Since everyone here likes different sauces, after I pull the pork I let everyone load it up on their buns and then add whichever sauce they want! Everone always asks for seconds!
Makes a great lunch the next day too! I put some pork in a microwave-safe container and add sauce on top. The bun is wrapped up in plastic wrap and put separate from the pork so that it won't get all soggy before lunch. Once the pork+sauce is warmed in the microwave, it is just a matter of scooping it out onto the bun! Delicious! :)

country:
None
text:
Love it! thank you! I use regular pork roast (cheaper cut) since I will cook in crockpot for 8hrs on low. and with the basics from this recipe I added a touch with 5oz of horseradish sauce rub on pork and slice 1/2 onion and use only 8oz of rootbeer or coke. If you do not like the smell or taste of onions then pass on the onion. The horseradish gives a savory flavor & brings out the 'meat sweetness' (not the sugary type of sweetness). I add horseradish sauce to rub on my beef too when I cook pot roast. give it a try!

userID:
3556785
Display Name:
mommabee
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a Super Bowl gathering last week and it turned out great.  I'd never made pulled pork before, so I was eager to try, but a bit worried about this unusual recipe.  Like others suggested, I used a cheaper/fattier cut of meat and cooked it in the crockpot.  I put the 4+ lb butt in the crockpot along with a 2L of rootbeer and cooked it on low overnight as one of the previous reviewers did.  It was bubbling and fully cooked the next morning (8 hrs).  I then removed the meat, cleaned off as much fat as possible while shredding the meat, and strained the liquid.  After cleaning the crock pot (messy from bubbling soda), I put the meat back in, added a bottle of barbecue sauce as well as plenty of the reserved rootbeer to fully cover the meat.  After stirring to mix the liquids, I put the crockpot in the frig for about 6 hrs to let it marinate further (as another reviewer suggested).  I then pulled it out, turned it on low for 2 hrs and high for 1 hr to thicken up the liquid some.  The meat was tender and flavorful and all of us enjoyed it.  I'll definitely make this again and do it more often, keeping some for leftovers and maybe freezing some.  I may experiment with barbecue sauces in the future but this basic, easy recipe is great is a winner as is!

userID:
2174086
Display Name:
In-a-Pickle
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
74
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/397212.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy! Less fatty and healthier if you use tenderloin but also drier. However, once you've added your BBQ sauce it doesn't really matter! I used a 12 oz bottle of root beer plus an entire bottle of beer to cover as much of the pork as possible, since I left it held together in the string. Easy to clean the crock pot afterwards since it was on Low, maybe the beer helped that. I might try it in just beer next time, maybe a dark one, or with half the amount of root beer. I wasn't keen on the smell of the simmering root beer. I also might try with a cheaper cut of pork next time and see if there really is more flavour. I followed others' advice and salt and peppered the roast, then pierced it all over with a knife and turned it over every couple of hours so all parts would have a chance to be in the liquid. Maybe this is why mine took 9 hours on Low to cook. I also threw in a clove of garlic for more flavour. It pulled apart easily. I had to then put it in the fridge overnight since it was too late to eat for dinner. I reheated the next day in a pot on the stove . I put some in a pot with just Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and a splash of cider vinegar, and some in a pot with a combination of Stubbs BBQ mopping sauce, Sweet Baby Ray's which my husband loved, since the Stubbs sauce is spicier and more vinegary. I prefer it sweeter myself, with a sprinkling of cheddar cheese. Served with homemade cole slaw. Yum!

text:
this was absolutely delicious. few things to keep in mind, and this saved me: 1) do not use pork tenderloin. the cut is not fatty enough, and way too expensive for this dish. use pork shoulder instead. 2) make sure to cover the beef in root beer, this may require more than one bottle. 3) i cooked this for the first time and got scared that it was so tough after 6 hours. it really softened in hour 7 and 8.

text:
I made this recipe at least five or six times already, and have always received rave compliments on my pulled pork!

I use pork shoulder or pork butt (so much cheaper for same results), pour in the root beer, and forget about it for 8 hours.

One night I only had 3 hours, so I cooked it on high for 3, and the pork wasn't tender enough to pull apart. I did the next best thing, sliced it up thinly, and put it back in the crock pot with Sweet Baby Ray's Brown Sugar BBQ sauce liberally slathered on everything. At the potluck, everyone RAVED about my BBQ pork, it may have been better received than my pulled pork!

Regardless, I love cooking pork this way - it's no fail tender pork! Thanks so much for the recipe!

text:
Mmmmm.  Delicious!  I poured about 20 ounces over a 3 pound pork sirloin roast and slow cooked it overnight, about 10 hours on low.  In the morning, I emptied the root beer out of the crockpot and shredded the pork (it literally fell apart), placed the pork back in the crockpot and added 2 cups of Bourbon Whiskey BBQ sauce from this site and cooked on high for 4 hours.  This was AWESOME.  My husband loved it!  Tender, juicy, and great flavor from the BBQ sauce.  Who would've thought root beet could tenderize this meat so well?  Looking forward to eating the leftovers tonight!

text:
I used 1.5 lbs of frozen boneless chicken breasts - since that's all I had.  Added spices & cooked in A&W root beer on high for ~1.5 hours.  Switched to low and cooked another 7 hours, flipping halfway through (I didn't have enough to cover the chicken and didn't want it to dry out).

Drained the root beer, added Ken Davis' Original BBQ sauce.  Shredded the chicken and cooked on high for about 20 more minutes.

My son said it was the best thing he'd ever eaten!  That alone gave it 5 stars.  :)   Will definitely make again!

country:
None
text:
Very good and extremely easy.  I bought a 4 lb boston butt roast and cooked it for 10 hours till the bone slipped out without resistance and the meat shredded easily.  I drained the slow cooker, shredded the meat, added the sauce and then stuck it back in the slow cooker for another 30 minutes.  I would suggest you use a spicy barbecue without a lot of sweetness.  I used a variety of Bullseye bbq sauce with molasses/brown sugar and the pulled pork is very sweet - almost too sweet.  Other than that, this 4 lb roast gave me enough for 16 sandwiches.

FANTASTIC & SIMPLE!!!  I used a 12 lb Pork Butt roast (which is perfect for pulled pork!) DELICIOUS!!! Cannot wait to make it again.  Thank you so much for the recipe!!

userID:
4567049
Display Name:
Bob C.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm sorry, but this was nothing special to me. I think an onion, garlic and maybe a stalk of celery would have been a better choice for flavor. The Root Beer gave it an off flavor that the BBQ sauce had to cover up. Keep in mind I'm not talking about a strong flavor, just a slight flavor of what I consider an off taste. I doubt if you will ever find someone identify a root beer taste unless you tell them beforehand.

Those that have smoked meat often will probably be puzzled why this flavor is desirable. I suspect to those that don't eat a lot of smoked meat, this gives them some sort of hint of a smoky flavor. 

Another mentioned using Dr. Pepper, and I suspect that might be a better choice. As far as some claiming the meat was dry, that is fixed with a simple solution that every competitor in a smoke-off contest uses. Right after cooking, wrap the meat (with juices) in aluminum foil tightly and then wrap it in a blanket, and let it set for one hour. The juices are pulled back in the meat as it cools "SLOWLY." In my case, it was as simple as reducing the Crockpot to "warm" (I have 3 settings high, low and warm) the last hour, and leave it to cool with the Crockpot turned off for an hour. It was really juicy. Only after this point to you discard the remaining juice.

As one person said, it stinks while cooking. This was the reason I cooked on the patio and after getting a whiff when opening the Crockpot, I would say they are right. I probably cooked it about 8 hours in all.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2816573.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used to make pulled pork that required a 2 day process, brining for a day and cooking the next.  No longer, this is now my go-to pulled pork method.  For health reasons I had to give up the brining, but would have anyway now that I've tried this.  I used diet root beer and Kinders BBQ, topped off by a healthly dollop or two of Dave's Ultimate Insanity Sauce.  Turned out sweet and Hot, just like I like it.  It verges on almost too sweet, but to me adding the heat from Dave's brings it all into balance.  And my wife, who is not a pepper head, likes it too, just omit the Dave's from hers.  Pairs nicely with French Sourdough bread!

text:
I've already made this twice! The first time I used root beer but I bought boston butt or pork shoulder and I used stubbs bbq sauce (2 bottles) and it was yummy! I cooked it on low almost all day and it was moist but didnt shred as easy as I
hoped, but still good. I just made it again but didnt have root beer and used 2 cans of coke instead and cooked it on high most of the day and used a very lean pork tenderloin and it pretty much shredded itself without the fat chunks! I used 2 bottles of bulls-eye and it was just as yummy if not better! This recipe is soo simple and is soo good! I suggest to follow the directions with the tenderloin cooked in coke, drained and add your fav bbq sauce. Easy

text:
Pulled pork is not a dish that we are familiar with in the UK but having tried it on holiday I was keen to find a recipe when back at home, so pleased I did, as this is now a family favorite. 

We do not have root beer so I used coke instead, used pork shoulder as per other reviews making it a much more economical meal. Also rubbed in some chilli seasoning mix to the pork before putting it in the slowcooker but when using a better brand bbq sauce I could miss this step.

Such a simple dish and by far the best slow cooker meal I have made.

country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe twice now. The first time was with a pork tenderloin cut, the second was with a pork blade roast (boston butt.) I highly recommend going with the boston butt, because the meat has more fat and it tastes a lot better that way. No matter if you're using 2 lbs or 8 lbs of roast, just cover the roast between 1/2 and 3/4 the way with root beer and cook it for 8 hours low and slow. Drain, pull, and sauce it up. Yum!

Overall I ended up with a fairly nice slab of meat. I don't believe the Root Beer did anything at all for the loin.  I had to use a rub from another recipe and glad I did because the meat would have been quite tasteless.  This recipe also loses points for asking you to use prepared barbeque sauce. So as a whole this recipe requires too many additions and judgements calls to give it a high rating as a stand alone.  I suggest trying a different pulled pork recipe altogether.

text:
One of the most delicious meals I have ever made. I used pork shoulder, but the butcher told me you can use pork butt/ pork steak and it will be just as good and cheaper than a tenderloin. I put cooking spray on the sides of the slow cooker to keep the root beer from sticking and burning. Followed the recipe to a T! Cooked for about 7/8 hours. Shredded the pork, pulled out the bone, doused the meat in Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce (a MUST!), let it cook for another hour (well, admittedly I took a bite from the slow cooker every 2 mins because it was so delicious). Outrageous! Can't wait to make it again.

So went to the store and they only had one package of a pork tenderloin left and didn't have anymore (I hate getting the last package of something, i know weird, lol) but I saw that they had turkey breast tenderloins availabe so I bought that.  Besides the change of the meat, I basically did as the recipe stated...root beer and Hunts honey bbq sauce ( i prefer Open Pit but couldn't find any).  It came out AMAZING!  Definitely not dry and very flavorful.  I could taste the root beer just a little but it wasn't overwhelming.  Would definitely make again!

text:
used 5 1/4 lbs pork shoulder.  trimmed as much fat as I could off of it.  used 2-20 oz. bottles of root beer to cover the roast.  drained off liquid in strainer after about 7 hours and shred it then added 1-18 oz. bottle sweet baby rays hickory bbq and 18 oz. regular sweet baby rays.  buttered the rolls and put in the oven.  Every one loved it.  you could take some pork out before adding bbq sauce and reserve it for tacos for the week.  my 5 lb. shoulder could have made at least 10-12 sandwhiches.  fed 6 adults with lots of leftovers.  served with chips and coleslaw.

Display Name:
SANDIGN47

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this numerous times and have made a couple of changes each time.  I always add a few onions slices cut up because I like the flavor. I also use a pork shoulder. But where I make some interesting changes is the soda.  I love the root beer but have used beer in the past and also Dr Pepper. I know that sounds strange but it's great.

Update: Last couple of times I made this I had added onion soup. I kept the sauce that was drained, put it in the refrigerator, scimmed off the fat the next day and froze it.  Today I add  little bit of pork, carrots, some water and put it back it the pressure cooker. Added some noodles and it as another whole meal. I've also added some potatoes instead of noodles in the past , thickened it a bit and had a great stew.  Really extends the original meal.

text:
I used what I had in the freezer, which was a pork tenderloin. I used diet A&W Rootbeer and cooked the pork until the thermometer reached the 170 temp, the the pork turned out very tender. Pulled apart very easily. I  made sure that I drained the pork well before I tossed it with bbq sauce and returning it to the slow cooker to warm completely  through. At the very end I added a few dashes liquid smoke, for a subtle smoke flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
had a 5 lb pork shoulder (bone in).  placed it in my 5 qt slow cooker.  poured in 2 cans of a&w root beer around the sides.  cooked it on low for 7 hours.  it still wasn't falling apart so cranked it up to high for 90 mins and it was done.  it was falling off the bone.    took out the pork and put it on a platter.  shredded it.  dumped the root beer and wiped clean the slow cooker.  put the shredded meat back into the slow cooker and poured 3/4's of an 18 oz bottle of stubb's smokey mesquite bbq sauce.  set it on low for 1 hour.  came out super moist and flavorful with the bbq sauce.  put potatoe rolls side up on a pan and set it under the broiler for 10-15 seconds.  served the pulled pork on them.  thanks for a simple and easy go to recipe to feed a bunch of folks for cheap.

Display Name:
jcb62

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/591464.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this, and it couldnt be any easier. Only thing I did different is I uses a 4.5 lb pork Boston butt roast. I coated the meat with my home made BBQ rub and put it in a ziplock with a bottle of good root beer (I used Frosty). I let that sit overnight. Next morning I tossed the roast into the crock pot with a fresh bottle of root beer, some fresh minced garlic and some liquid smoke and cooked on low for about 6 hours. This is where you have to watch not to over cook it. Some people complained it was 'mushy', I assume from being overcooked.  I turned the roast as it cooked and broke it up as I went. When it was cooked I dumped the liquids, shredded the meat ( tossing as much of the fat as I could pull out. Then put back in crock with a bottle of Montgomery Inn BBQ sauce and cooked another.  I've cooked pulled pork before, and this was the best results. Served with home made baked beans and a salad for a true BBQ feast. I'll make again.

city:

None
text:
Family loved this and very simple to make.  I used the pork butt about 4 lbs.  Feed us four with 2 full plates for left overs.   Went with the small rolls to serve.   My 13 yo thought it was awesome.   Used the dried onion flakes, some s&p and turned over the meat mid-way.   I had it on slow cook for only about 6.5 hours (mostly because I forgot to start on time).   It forked apart effortlessly at 6.5 hours.   I drained off juice (and fat) from the crock, replaced the now-pulled pork and reconstituted the meat using about a 1/3 of bottle of BBQ sauce.   I went light because I didn't want to loose the nice hint of root beer.   Some added more sauce at the table but most liked the mild but not over-sauced flavors (including me).

text:
My fiance loves to order BBQ pulled pork almost every time we go out to eat ANYWHERE! (Including places like Cheesecake Factory.) It's one of his favorite go-to American foods. One night, he had a taste for them but we're now on a strict budget for our wedding. So I suggested he look online for a recipe. He found this one, so I picked up the ingredients, and he prepared it the next morning. When I got home from work, I drained it and put the bbq sauce in there. I never would've thought to use Root-beer to flavor the meat. This is just as good if not better than the pulled pork they serve in restaurants. This is a go-to recipe on a hectic work week for us now. Thanks!

text:
so easy and so good. i used pork shoulder (boston butt) and rubbed salt, pepper, and garlic salt all around it. dumped it right into the crock pot with a the root beer. Afterwards, emptied the juices from the pot, added a 1 sliced onion to the bottom of the pot, then the shredded pork with bbq sauce mixed in it. After an hour or so, i mixed everything together. oh boy...i cant stop eating it. OH! and for an extra kick to the bbq sauce, i added sriracha hot sauce (thai hot sauce with a rooster logo on it).

userID:

Display Name:
Riceboi

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used about 6 pork sirloins, which was a total of about 4lbs of pork, and it's a lot more lean than a pork shoulder, and a lot cheaper than the tenderloin. I had to put about 5-6 cups of MUG root beer for the soda to cover the meat, which I recommend doing. I also recommend marinading the pork the night before cooking in a mesquite type of mix. I used McCormick GrillMates Mesquite flavor. When making the marinade I add a few extra spices like cayenne pepper, red pepper flakes, white vinegar and some whisky. Also when I went to cook the pork in the morning I add about 4 tsp of minced garlic to the crockpot. I cooked it on low for about 11-12 hours and it was so easy to pull apart, it was breaking in half when taking it out. I recommend saving about 203 cups of the rootbeer mix from teh crockpot to spread over the pork after done shredding it.  I didn't use the BBQ sauce and mix it all together to cook longer because I wanted to use some of the pork for tacos as well, and I didn't want the BBQ sauce on the meet. Awesome recipe, and I will use this one from now on. Thanks!

text:
Simple.  It came out perfectly.  We used a pork shoulder roast and cooked it for about 7 hours with our solar oven. The meat and root beer were in a black ceramic pot with a glass lid.  The trick is keeping the temperature low enough (not full-on sun).  We turned it over a few times and on the last attempt it fell apart, just right ....

We also made corn bread (  http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Grandmothers-Buttermilk-Cornbread/Detail.aspx )


and coleslaw ( http://allrecipes.com//Recipe/restaurant-style-coleslaw-i/Detail.aspx )


... add the bbq sauce and some baked beans. We thought we had died and gone to deep south food overload heaven.

text:
I made this recipe for the first time today and it was very good!  I used what I had on hand - a 2lb pork tenderloin, one 12 oz can of Diet Barq's Root Beer, and a 14 oz bottle of Danielle's PNW Sweet & Spicy BBQ Sauce.  I served it on toasted Sweet Onion Buns with Coleslaw and some Baked Kettle Chips.  I also topped each sandwhich with a bit of Dijon mustard and chopped red onion.  Very good flavor and easy as recipe is written and it made enough for my husband and I to have sandwiches all week.  I like my BBQ a little more spicy so I left the leftovers in the crockpot on warm and added some McCormicks Steak Seasoning and let it meld for a few more hours.  Very, very good!  Will go into our monthly menu rotation.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing! I have been wanting to try this for a while and I am so glad I finally did! I am giving this recipe 4 stars because I added about 5 other ingredients that I think really helped the overall flavor of the dish. I used a 7 lb. bone in shoulder cut. I seasoned it very generously with Slap Ya Mama (cajun seasoning) and I also rubbed it down with some liquid smoke. I cooked it on low for 6 1/2 hours with a bottle of IBC rootbeer and a small can of beef broth. I also added an onion and about 4 cloves of garlic. I took it out the slow cooker to shred it and it was just falling apart it was so tender. I was very nervous about the rootbeer but it was actually really nice. I could taste it but it was very subtle. It just gave it a nice sweetness. When I added all the pork back into the slowcooker I left a little bit of the juice and then I used an entire 40 oz. bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory & Brown Sugar barbeque sauce. I had some of the honey bbq on hand too so I added a little bit of that too. I continued to cook for another hour on low. Yummy!!!! I will definitely be making this again and again and again!!!!

text:
Very easy and delicious. I followed other commenters suggestions and used a shoulder roast purely to save money. The only other thing I changed was I seasoned the roast with salt and garlic before cooking. I left it in the slow cooker for 7 hours, drained the majority of the drippings, shredded the pork, and added a generous amount of Sweet Baby Rays Honey BBQ sauce. I then refrigerated it overnight, took it out in the morning and put it back of the slow cooker on low for another 4 hours. It was delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Needed something simple. This was it!  I used two tenderloins (2.7 lbs total) and rubbed them heavily with McCormick's Barbecue seasoning, placed them in crockpot and slowly added 1 1/2 cans Barqs rootbeer.  Cooked on high for 6 1/2 hours, then shredded the pork, drained the rootbeer off, stirred in 1/2 - 3/4 c. Jack Daniels #7 BBQ sauce and let heat through 30 minutes.  Served on homemade hamburger rolls (allrecipes, too) with additional BBQ for putting on top.  Husband and kids raved.

text:
Good, not great.  I used a shoulder cut, rubbed with garlic powder, salt and pepper for a moist pull in the crock pot.  I used A&W Rootbeer nearly to cover the roast, but supplemented with vinegar.  Cooked overnight before pulled, drained and tossed with Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce in the morning.  Guests raved, but the flavor was a bit too sweet for me.  I'll experiement with other marinades in the future.

Made this last night. My husband said if he'd ordered it at a restaurant, he'd have been very pleased. I used the tenderloin-- yes, more expensive, but much, much leaner. No grease. text:
This was so easy and tasted great! Served on whole wheat buns with sweet pickle chips. I was surprised at how tender the meat was....the rootbeer really added a little something special. I did have a little trouble trying to drain the liquid from the meat. I ended up just forking the roast into a spare bowl, emptying the rootbeer down the drain and then putting the roast back in my slow cooker and adding the barbecue sauce. I will definitely make this again. It was inexpensive to prepare and very tasty. Next time I make this will separate and freeze individual serving sizes.

text:
I'd browned my pork loin (4-5 pounds), but when I put it in the crock pot, I realized I was missing an ingredient in the recipe. A few clicks later, I found this recipe. I'd never heard of cooking meat in root beer, but I had it and decided to give it a try. ... I poured in a can of A&W, and cooked it on Low for about 7 hours. ...The meat fell apart without any help. I put it in the fridge (crock and all) without pulling it apart or draining the fluid and exchanging it for BBQ sauce. ... We're adding sauce as we take the meat out (the meat fell apart by itself).  I like it plain, or with a mild BBQ; my husband has tried BBQ sauce and other spicy stuff. It's so good! I'll definitely make this over and over!

text:
Super easy and very tasty!  I've tried more complicated pulled pork recipes for the slow cooker and this one is by far the one my family likes the best!  One change, though ... instead of a pork tenderloin, I use pork butt (a.k.a. Boston butt).  I tried the tenderloin, but the butt is much more flavorful for this recipe, and it's less expensive.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My Family loved this. It was quick, easy, and very filling. We even had enough left for lunch the next day. I changed it up a bit. I seasoned the meat and put it in the crock. Then I added a full bottle of bbq sauce (I added water to half the bottle, shook it, and added it in) and stirred until coated. I poured root beer in until meat was just about covered. Cooked it for several hours (4 on high). Then I added in diced onions and stirred. Let cook for 2 more hours then drained. Shredded meat then added a large bottle of bbq sauce. Put back in for about 45 minutes to heat up sauce. Served on sesame buns. Great with coleslaw and tots.

text:
I made this for a large gathering and it was a huge hit!  I used a 10# pork butt, covered with rootbeer, added a lot of honey over the top and cooked on low for about 9 hrs.  Drained and used Sweet Baby Ray's (my personal favorite)  and cooked on low for another couple of hours.  It was a large pot luck, and it was the first thing eaten!  Many people were disappointed they didn't get to try it after all the glowing reviews!  My brother-in-law was even impressed, which has only happened one other time in 20 yrs.  Super easy, inexpensive and delicious!

text:
This was excellent and so easy.  It was my first time trying pulled pork. I used a 3 1/2 lb sirloin pork roast.  Put in slow cooker with 12oz root beer.  Cooked on low 6-7 hours.  Did flip over half way thru.  Took out roast and shredded with forks.  Left only about 1/4 of liquid and then mixed the pork with 1/2 bottle Sweet Baby Rays.  Placed on toasted rolls.  Served with coleslaw and roasted potatoes.

I will say that the look of using a tenderloin is not as appealing as using a butt/shoulder and since the shoulder is also cheaper I will use that in the future.  Thanks!

text:
Quite wonderful and so dang easy, I just cut my 4lb pork loin in half, covered it with 1 can of Mugg root beer and cooked it for 10 hours on low. I took it out of the crock pot and shredded it and tossed with Sweet Baby Rays sauce and put in the oven for 1/2 hour, which I think is a little sweet, I would try something smokier next time. I served the meat with sourdough rolls and the left overs on tortillias...everyone loved it.

text:
Cream soda works too, if you don't have rootbeer.  Use about a cup and then add chicken broth (2 cups) when there's about an hour left of cooking time.  Drain the cooking liquid with about a half hour left to go and add BBQ sauce.  Shred meat before serving and stir it in the sauce.  Yummy AND easy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, but it needs  rub!!  Although slow cooking is "cheating" over smoking for such a meal, the weather does not always allow for that.  I rubbed the pork roast (not tenderloin) with Montreal Seasoning, let it sit, jabbed it with a knife and added liquid smoke flavoring.  With a few more drops after pulled mixed in with BBQ sauce, it makes you think this was smoked, then slow cooked in sauce as a finisher.  All obviously a personal preference, but think of it as a difference between boiled ribs with sauce on them at the end, or smoked/grilled ribs.  I would watch the saltiness though, as liquid smoke and most rubs are high in sodium content.  Enjoy!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I have prepared this several times now and it is excellent.  The family loves it, so I usually have to double or triple the recipe. My only changes have been in the final stage, where I add a very finely diced onion and garlic to the shredded pork and then top with "Sweet Baby Ray's" BBQ sauce, then slow cook again the next day. My grandson always requests this dish and asks me to make extra so he can take some home with him.  I think that alone rates as a 5 star recipe :)   Thanks for the great recipe.  L.

text:
I made this for my son's graduation party.  I have never made pulled pork before so I was a little nervous.  The butcher recommended pork shoulder, which is also called Boston butt.  I cooked the pork in the crock pot, drained it, pulled it and added Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce on Thursday.  Reheated it to serve it Friday evening.  I had rave reviews from my guests.  I made 10 pounds of meat and there was nothing left.  Except for using a different cut of meat, I made the recipe exactly as written and it was wonderful! Thank you to Lori Wagner for such a great recipe!

Very Good and Super EASY!!!  I left mine in a crockpot for 9 hours while I was at work.  Came home to a wonderful smelling house and all I had to do was shred and throw in some BBQ sauce and Voila!  Very Good!  **Addition** I have since revised my version of this recipe.  I use the seasoning from "Slow Cooker Carnitas".  Just cover the tenderloin in the seasoning, and place in in the crockpot with the Rootbeer.  It's amazing!  Try it!

text:
I just moved from North Mississippi and have been missing pulled pork sandwitches ever since.   So, I decided to make my own, and this recipe made my year!  I omitted the Root Beer. (didn't have any)  I usually get 2 - 2.5 lb pork rump roasts, rub them with salt and pepper, poke holes throughout and put in the crock-pot with 1 bottle of bbq sauce.  (I Like Stubbs spicy)  After about 5 1/2 - 6 hours on low, I pull the pork from the bone, and put back in the crock pot for another hour or so.  Serve on Keiser rolls.  ENJOY, I sure do :)

text:
We seasoned 1.5kg of pork shoulder with salt, garlic and pepper before setting it to slow-cook with 750ml of A&W Root Beer.  Since we didn't have a slow cooker, we put it on stove top at medium-high heat till it boiled, then simmered it on low heat for 3 hours and it turned out tender. The root beer brought out the taste of the pork so wonderfully, I can't believe it!! Everyone in the family wanted a 2nd serving, and that's a lot to say for a choosy family of 6!! Perfect. 

(We also made our own hamburger buns using another recipe on this website. Unfortunately we couldn't find sweet Ray here too, so we got Masterfood's BBQ sauce instead: still delicious.)

text:
This was absolutely DELICIOUS.  I used an 8 pound pork shoulder (why use tenderloin?!?!?), which I cooked in the crock pot covered in the root beer on low for 15 hours.  Drained it and the pork was falling off the bone.  Put the shredded pork in a roasting pan, mixed in two bottles of Sweet Baby Rays and then cooked it with a lid on for another 30 ish minutes at 325.  

Served it at a super bowl party with homemade slaw (the Sweet Restaurant Slaw recipe on this site) and potato buns and all 8 pounds was gone by the end of the night!

text:
This was perfect for our party. I used a bone-in Boston butt, dried it, stabbed it a few times and rubbed with salt, pepper & garlic salt at another reviewer's suggestion. This cooked on low for 8 hours covered in root beer, and then we shredded it and put it back in the crock for an hour mixed with Sweet Baby Ray's sauce.  So many compliments, and I shared the recipe with two others already. I considered that another sauce would've given it more of a kick, but it really was perfect for those who didn't want anything spicy.  Can easily serve it with other sauce options to top off.  We ate the rest all week, and it only got better by the day. Will definitely make this again.
