text:
I think that anything good about this recipe comes from the BBQ sauce that you use. As it is, I was not overwhelmed by the taste of the pork alone, I thought the rootbeer taste was kind of off, but drowned in lots of sauce it was fine, with just a bit of an aftertaste. I've done this before with Coke, and I much prefer that taste, I think (although that recipe also used a pork shoulder, so it may or may not be an apt comparison).

The meat did turn out nice and tender though. I found that just shredding it gave me really long, chewy strands, so I sliced it into chunks of about 1 inch and then lightly shredded it, which gave it a better texture and meant my kids didn't make Chewbacca noises, which they do whenever meat is too chewy.

text:
This recipe worked very well with a 7.5 pound shoulder roast and a 20oz bottle of root beer. This required a larger slow cooker - the 7.5 lb roast was too big for the standard Crock Pot.  Used one 18 oz bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ sauce after the long cook, then had another bottle for topping the sandwiches.  Served with coleslaw and baked beans.  Big hit and easy cooking for a large crowd!

country:

text:
Very good but not over the moon about it. I used a 8#+  boneless  butt (shoulder). Trimmed off as much visible fat as possible --I think tenderloin would be too dry.  Started in Slow-cooker on high then turned down to low after about 2 hours--that butt  nearly filled the crock.  Used most of 2 cans root beer and seasoned with a good amount of Morton All-Season. It was done after about 7 hours. Meat fell apart without the need to "shred".  Drained off all root beer juice. As I mixed in the BBQ sauce  (Sweet Baby Ray's, is there any other?) meat  continued to disintegrate. All in all  very tasty but not pretty. Next time will use cola instead of  root beer.and probably won't cook as long.

text:
A great "starting point" recipe. I have made this 4 or five times and it's always a hit. Add what you like to the pot to suit your tastes. I rub roast (pork butt not tenderloin) with a dry marinade and let it set for an hour. Put it in the pot and add the root beer, a quartered onion and a large clove of garlic. I also let it set over night, scrape of the fat, and then reheat, drain, pull and serve with favorite sauce.

Display Name:
Parvati48

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5646617.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this pulled pork a few times already and I have to say I love it, it's simple to do, it gives the meat a nice sweet taste that I enjoy, especially paired with Honey BBQ, and it's great on Sweet Hawaiian Hamburger buns. The only things I've changed is I use Pork shoulder because it's cheaper, and it pulls apart much better, and I add a little seasoning on top like Garlic salt, Season salt, and Onion Powder before pouring the Root beer just to add a little more flavor but otherwise it doesn't need it. I also followed the advice of a few reviewers by draining and shredding the pulled pork an hour before it was done, taking out the bone, and then adding the BBQ Sauce (I've used Kraft Honey BBQ sauce) and then putting it back in to cook for that last hour. When you do that the BBQ soaks into the meat and it's SO good! Will definitely make this over and over again, even my picky eater husband loves it, and so do our friends who've tried it. :)

This is fantastic! The only thing I do differently is to put the pork back in the juices after shredding it and then putting the BBQ sauce on it right before serving. My husband and I like spicy BBQ sauce but my daughter doesn't so this way everyone gets what they want and by putting the shredded pork back in the juices it doesn't dry out.

text:
This has become a go-to recipe for us. I used the suggestions from several different posts to get to our preferred method: I use boneless pork ribs (country style), trim off the fat, salt and pepper and put in the crock pot with the root beer. When done cooking, I pull out and shred in a large casserole dish, mix in the bbq sauce, and then put in the oven at 300 for about 20-30 minutes or until the bbq sauce starts to carmelize then serve. I get rave review and people always ask for the recipe.

text:
This is my go to pulled pork recipe.  I tweek it a little and don't put the barbeque sauce over it.  I buy a pork shoulder butt, better piece of meat for pulled pork. I always stab mine with a fork, then season with salt, pepper and garlic powder before placing in the crock pot, then pour a whole bottle of root beer over it.  Turn on and go to bed.  As a 3rd shift nurse, I need quick crock pot recipes.  Make a little rice and beans, add some salsa, cheese, sour cream and guacamole and you have burrito bowls one night.  Pulled pork sandwiches the next.  Recommend to all the nurses at work.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is the first time making pulled pork. I took a suggestion from a friend who is a butcher to use shoulder pork to make this. Since I was making it for a party, I purchased 8 pounds of sliced pulled pork which ended costing $2.49 per lb. I used a full bottle of Freddy's root beer, 26 oz bottle and it barely covered the pork. Cooked it slow for 5 hours and it then turned it up to high the last 1 1/2 hours since I was running short on time. Drained the juices and shredded the pork with 2 forks. It took a while since some of the pork wasn't as tender. Then placed it back in the crock pot and pour a full big bottle of Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce. Cooked it on high for another hour. I had rave reviews and said to make it again at my next party. You couldn't taste the root beer at all. I estimated about 1/2 lb per person since I had 14 over and had about 1 lb left over. The only thing I would do different next time is not to use a crock pot liner since it seemed to take longer to cook things. But great recipe. I guess I need to make it again. Thanks!

Made this the first time "exactly"  using "Sweet Baby Rays" Sweet & Spicy BBQ Sauce w/ Calif. Slaw.  It was very good  HOWEVER the  Second time I added 3/4 tsp cayenne pepper, 1/4 tsp black pepper and 1/2 tsp salt. :) Much better, sweet with a very nice spice kick at the end of each bite. We also made Apple Slaw (using vidalia sweet onion instead of green onions).  You can find both slaw recipes  on this site also.  WOW NOW we have a Unique Family and Party Dish At potlucks this crock pot is wiped out..... FAST.

This recipe is not that different from any pulled pork recipe that you can find anywhere else, but yet it has the root beer as ingredient that makes it more interesting. I have seen that some peole add apple cider or any other liquid but I found that the root beer gives it a special touch. text:
This was really amazing. My first time cooking pulled pork. At first seeing one of the recipes was root beer made me second think but as i read reviews from others i was excited to try this. I used a tip from another reviewer and rubbed black pepper and kosher salt before putting it in the slow cooker. used pork shoulder and filled the crock pot until the meat was covered. cooked for about 6-7 hours until the meat started to fall apart and i used rays honey and brown sugar to coat the pork. i let the pork sit for another hour to soak up the flavor of the bbq sauce. but definately amazing!

text:
Soooo i added to the recipe a little! First i rubbed the tenderloin with sage,onion powder, garlic powder, coriander,cayenne pepper, paprika salt and pepper. Drizzled with olive oil and refrigerated overnight. The next day i browned the pork in my cast iron skillet on all sides then placed in crockpot with 1 yellow onion sliced and 1 tbl spoon minced garlic. Poured in the root beer and cooked on low for 61/2-7hrs!

I made this once before, and the first time it was nothing to write home about. Too sweet & a bit boring. Deserving 3 stars, at best.

This time around, I added 1 chicken bouillon cube, 4 cloves of minced garlic & 1 onion. Normally I prefer a sweet and tangy bbq sauce, but since the root beer is sweet, I used a basic hickory sauce. I added it about halfway through. 
Method #2 wins all 5 stars! (So I averaged the two results) :)

I did rub it with salt, pepper and garlic salt before pouring the root beer over it. Other than that, I followed the recipe. I'm making it again tomorrow for a party. It will be a keeper.

text:
Like others, I used a pork shoulder instead of a tenderloin - more bang for your buck!  It was incredible.  So easy.  I rubbed the meat with salt, pepper and garlic powder and then covered it in root beer.  Set it on low for 8 hours flipping it part way through, and it came out amazing.  My only "complaint" was that it was hard to drain because it was so easily falling apart!!!  Not a bad complaint to have.  I mixed it with Pork Butt BBQ sauce and let it sit on warm while I put my baby to bed.  I will absolutely be making this again!

text:
I made this EXACTLY as was stated in the recipe, pork tenderloin and all, and it was literally AMAZING!!! So amazing in fact, that my husband had FOUR of these pulled pork sandwiches! The ONLY thing I might do differently next time is add more root beer so that it completely covers the meat. Since I only used one 12 oz. bottle of root beer, it didn't even come close to covering the meat, so I felt like I had to constantly flip it to keep it from drying out. Otherwise, everything is PERFECT with this recipe!

text:
This pork was DELICIOUS. I only made a few small tweaks to the recipe. Instead of tenderloin, I bought a 3 pound cut of Boston butt. I used diet root beer instead of regular for calorie's sake, and honestly, I could have used two bottles instead of one. The whole pork was extremely moist, besides the top that stuck out of the root beer bath. After 6 hours of cooking on low, I drained off the root beer and poured a whole bottle of Sticky Fingers Carolina Sweet Barbecue sauce over it. After one more hour of cooking on low, the meat practically fell off the bone! It was so moist and flavor-packed. I can't wait to make this recipe again... 5 thumbs up!!!

text:
I was looking for a BBQ pulled pork recipe to put on top of nachos, and came across this one. I used a pork shoulder instead of a tenderloin, but otherwise followed the recipe. It was absolutely delicious, but I'm not convinced that the root beer actually did anything for the recipe. I couldn't taste it (probably a good thing) - I could only taste the BBQ sauce (Sweet Baby Ray's Honey Barbecue Sauce). 

That being said, I love how easy it was to make this and this BBQ pulled pork on nachos with black beans, onions, tomatoes and cheese is a must try.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first time I've ever made pulled pork and this was certainly an easy recipe to follow. I also used pork butt instead of pork loin and used enough A&W root beer to cover the meat. I followed advice and cooked on low for 6 hours. Took it out of the cooker, shredded the meat, which was easy to do, and then mixed it in with Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce. Placed it back in the slow cooker and refridgerated overnight. Put it on simmer for about an hour or so before dinner. The recipe gets three stars for ease but the flavor comes from the BBQ sauce so be sure to find a sauce that you like (I personally love Sweet Baby Rays). That being said, I will most definitely be using this recipe again. It's already on the menu for the superbowl.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simply Easy! Amazing taste.  Rubbed salt, pepper and garlic powder on pork.  Used boneless pork shoulder. Cheaper than tenderloin  About $2.50 per lb.  Cut the pork into 3 large pieces and sear the pork in my dutch oven.  Added a can of root beer and slow cook on stove top for about 3 hours or until meat is tender. Didn't pour any liquid out.  It evaporated.   Did not use a whole bottle of sweet baby ray bbq sauce. but  Just enough for my liking.  Served it on hamburger buns and over rice.  Will definitely make again!

text:
This never lasts long at my house.  My kids love it, and with homemade buns it makes this recipe awesome.  I have made this a couple of times, and I will sometimes add a liquid smoke spay (couple of squirts) and a couple of teaspoons of Worcestershire sauce.  I also like to find a charcoal BBQ sauce, it gives it more of a grilled taste which enhances the BBQ experience.  I have tried Pepsi and Coke slow cookers and they are not as good as root beer.  Also what makes this so great is it can be cooked in the garage on hot days and not warm up my house!

This is an awesome recipe!  I don't really change anything.  I do use a picnic roast instead of a tenderloin.  I cook on low for about six or seven hours then drain the liquid, shred and put it back in on "keep warm" for another hour with the BBQ sauce.  You can taste the root beer a little, but it ends up being good anyway.  It's a sure fire way to get great pulled pork!

text:
As is, recipe is only a 3. (I have used a plain pork tenderloin before to "save" a recipe, and discovered it was not easy to shred nor as tasty as a shoulder. So I used a ~2.6 lb pork tenderloin roast, which had more fat). After following other suggestions with letting it sit in crock pot on 'keep warm' setting for an additional hour, which ended up being 1½ since had errands to run,  it raised review a point. I used Sweet Baby Rays Hickory and Brown Sugar BBQ sauce which is my favorite- but that still was inadequate. Once I added approximately 1 to 1½ tablespoons of Apple Cider Vinegar, it finally had that special punch to it, and became a 5.

text:
Just a thought...I make a very similar recipe with cola instead of root her with a few extra tweaks. I see a lot of posts about using a cheaper cut, totally agree, however tonight a tenderloin was what I had thawed and pulled pork sounded yummy. So, for a little added flavor try dicing up a few slices of bacon and about half an onion(depending on amount of meat,mine was 2 pounds) and lightly brown together. They do not have to be fully cooked as they will continue in the crockpot. Just a quick tip for extra flavor, mine always comes out awesome and full of flavor!

text:
This was so tasty!  I added a few things based on other reviews...minced onions, salt and pepper rubbed onto both sides of pork, and then turned over about half way thru, approx 3 hours in as I let it go for 6.  I drained it well but made sure to keep any of the yummy bits that had come off.  I also added some honey to the BBQ sauce I used, which is Sweet Baby Ray's Original, along with a little garlic powder.  Now, if I were making this for myself, I would have added Raspberry Jalapeno jelly for a little kick.

Yummy, but a little sweet for the hubby.  I changed it up by decreasing the RB to 1-1/4 cup and adding a 1/4 c apple cider vinegar.
Turned the meat halfway through, salted, lightly covered with white pepper and added 1/2 tsp. whole black peppercorns.  
Used Sticky Fingers Memphis style as the mix in and "Kermit's key lime chipotle" as a condiment-sliced sweet onions and potato rolls.

Sweet with a kick!

text:
Surprisingly good! I can always appreciate a good meal that doesn't require a lot of time or work and this is definitely one. I took someone else's suggestion and seasoned the meat. As well I took the suggestion of pouring off the root beer when close to done, shredding the pork and placing it back in the slow cooker and covering it with the bar-b-q sauce to cook awhile longer. It worked out perfectly.

text:
Excellent and very tasty!  I covered the entire tenderloin in root beer and put in slow cooker. After I drained the root beer and pulled the pork apart, I put back into the slow cooker with Honey BBQ sauce until it was hot, and served. The great reviews from family and friends were all day long!  Delicious!  TIP:  If you buy a whole pork tenderloin and cut into 3 roasts, seriously you will pay a total of about  $7.00-$10.00 more for the entire full tenderloin, then one small pork tenderloin. Trim fat, store other roasts in freezer for future use.

country:
None
text:
I used to eat pulled pork until I refrigerated the leftovers and saw all the fat congealed throughout.   Then I came across this recipe, and although I was concerned it would be lacking in flavor, decided to give it a try.  AMAZING! So simple, delicious, and so much healthier than my old recipe that used a fattier cut of pork.  I didn't make any changes (nothing to change, really).  My kids, who in the past, didn't like pulled pork, loved it!  I used Sticky Fingers Smokehouse Memphis bar-b-que sauce.  My one recommendation is to get a sauce you know you like.  Since its a big part of the flavor, don't skimp on the sauce!  I will definitely recommend this to my friends!!!

text:
After reading all of the reviews for this recipe, I also decided to use a pork butt.  IT WAS AWESOME!! I thought it was fantastic, and my boyfriend said he "was kind of in love with it".  This was my first pulled pork recipe and also my first use of a slow cooker.  I had a 4lb. butt, used Jones root beer, and put 1 onion on the bottom, set it to 8 hours& that was it!! When it was ready, I drained it skimmed the fat out, added some of the juice back in, and topped it with the "Absolutely Awesome BBQ Sauce" also from AR.  Thank you for the great recipe!!

text:
Fantastic pulled pork! I cooked pork butt (no need for the more expensive cuts, as others have mentioned) on low for seven hours with the root beer (I seasoned with a little garlic plus salt and pepper before putting in crockpot), then drained and shredded the pork, and put back into the crockpot with Famous Dave's BBQ sauce (more than the recipe calls for) AND a little more root beer. I let that cook for another hour or so and served on pretzel rolls. With a couple sides, this served 10 people.

text:
By far the best slow cooker pulled pork we've made to date.  I used a 3 lb pork roast with a 12 oz can of Hansens natural root beer and cooked it on low for about 8 hours then shredded it and added Kraft hickory smoke bbq sauce to it (~ 1.5 bottles).  The meat was considerably more moist than it's been in the past.

country:
None
text:
As others have done, I used a 7lb pork shoulder, removed some of the fat and the skin which was still intact.  I used two bottles of beer to mostly cover the meat.  After 8 hours in the crockpot, on low, the meat fell off the bone and smelled wonderful.  I drained the liquid, shredded the meat, and applied Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce (almost a whole bottle).  The meat remained in the crockpot for a few hours (accidentally while we visited with our guests).  When we finally ate, it was perfect, and very easy clean up!

text:
So simple! This recipe is delicious as it is, but can easily be tweaked to your taste buds. If you don't like the taste of root beer, try using Pepsi or Dr. Pepper instead; just make sure not to use the diet version. If you are looking for more flavor, add BBQ sauce as a condiment to your sandwich, or try adding in minced onions, minced garlic, oregano, basil or even salt and pepper as it cooks.

text:
First I must say it is oh so very simple and delish! I agree with  reviews saying that pork loin is not the best choice. Butt or shoulder is great. I have made this recipe several times (10-15!) as my large family loves pulled pork sandwiches. A few drops of liquid smoke added to a full liter of rootbeer gives us our favorite flavor. (If you use liquid smoke, be careful not to over do it. You do not need very much! ) Changing the BBQ sauce can give you a slightly different flavor each time. We love heat in our family so homemade spicy sauce is our preference although this recipe still is wonderful even with your bargain BBQ sauce. Yummy yummy yummy. Enjoy!

text:
This was shockingly (to me) good.  I had mediocre, at best, expectations.  But it was something simple, with limited ingredients that seemed like it would fill up a crowd.  

It came out delicious and was probably the most tender meat I've ever cooked.

One suggested modification - I just can't wrap my brain around buying a top cut of meat (tenderloin) and then killing it in the crockpot for 7-8 hours.  So I used a pork shoulder and it was wonderful, as well as inexpensive.  

I'm a recipe "tweaker" for sure, and I can't recommend one other modification to this three ingredient recipe.

text:
Okay...hmm. Made this exactly as written.  Ended up with meat that was so mushy, it was almost off-putting.  I now see why several other reviewers said that pork loin is not the ideal meat for a slow-cooked pulled pork recipes. I wish I had used a tougher cut of meat.  The flavor was good, it was just the texture..no substance to it at all.  So, a good recipe, but avoid the tenderloin, use something tougher so you don't feel like you are eating bbq pork flavored mashed potatoes!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My wife and I just love this recipe! It's SUPER easy and you can really taste the soda in the meat even after you slather on the BBQ sauce. I've tampered with the recipe a few times and I have a great redo. I use Dr. Pepper instead of Root Beer from time to time just to make it different since we have it so much. I also use almost an entire two liter instead of just one can so that the pork is completely submerged. It keeps it really moist and adds a lot of the soda flavor, but not so much that it's overbearing. I also add some Celery Seed and Mustard Seed into the BBQ sauce and after I've shredded the pork, I mix it all together and put it back in the slow cooker for another 30-60 minutes.

text:
I chose this recipe because of the health factor - tenderloin is lower in fat than the typical selections for pulled pork. It was a great choice and the recipe is definitely a keeper! 

I followed the directions (except the rolls) verbatim and used Bulls Eye BBQ sauce, as it is a bit sweeter than some other sauces, and served it on whole grain pita bread. It was a big hit for everyone, for sure. 

Next time, as there will be a next time soon, I think I will probably add some chopped onion, garlic and jalapeno in the mix and, possibly, another 4 ounces of BBQ, as I really like it dripping. 

A couple people mentioned that a tenderloin is harder to 'pull', but I found it worked very well. I had it shredded in a matter of minutes without much effort at all...

Display Name:
Gotrecipe?

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have fixed this twice now.  1st Time:  Exactly to recipe using 1/2 Williams BBQ Sauce (from Atlanta) and 1/2 Jack Daniels BBQ Sauce...Result? Liked it!  2nd Time:  I took several of the other viewers advice using Boston Butt, salt & pepper, garlic, etc. forking meat before adding the root beer.  The meat was moist but it took longer to shred to get rid of the extra fat that was on the boston butt compared to a drier meat from the tenderloin.  Also the liquid didn't smell so good with all those extra flavors mixed in with the root beer....though the flavor of the meat itself was fine.  This time I made a mixture of 1/2 Sticky Fingers, 1/2 Bone Lickin' Sauces, some yellow mustard and a dash or so of liquid smoke and used this for the BBQ Sauce.  Result?  Still liked it!  So my take on this recipe is that no matter what you do to the meat/root beer mixture, it's all in the BBQ Sauce that you use that will determine the number of stars this recipe gets.  Find the right BBQ Sauce and you have a Winner!!  Thanks Livie's Mammy for an easy, tasty recipe.

text:
This was my first time making pulled pork sandwiches. This was also by far the best pulled sandwiches I have ever tried! I did make a few minor changes. Instead of a can of root-beer, I used a can of beef broth. I rubbed in spices as well into the pork before placing into the slow cooker such as fresh chopped garlic, oregano, salt, and pepper. I let the pork cook on slow for 6.5 hours and then shredded it and added more spices including cayenne pepper and let that cook an extra hour. I also took the buns and added butter to the inside and cooked on the skillet on medium heat for a couple minutes until toasted. 

My boyfriend stuffed jalapeno peppers with cheddar cheese and bacon and cooked that in the oven for 15 minutes as a side. 

Over-all this made a great dinner!!!

text:
Used this recipe today for pulled pork sandwiches only I used a 4 lb shoulder picnic pork roast. I was concerned that using just the root beer wouldn't give the meat much flavor, so I added a couple onion wedges, some BBQ rub, a bay leaf, and some smashed garlic cloves to the liquid in the slow cooker. The meat was tender and ready to shred after about 6 hours in the slow cooker, but I was disappointed with the flavor. It was actually rather bland until I added the BBQ sauce. I also added more BBQ rub, some worcestshire sauce and some liquid smoke to the shredded meat. My family thought it was good. I will probably use this recipe again, but may need to try other some other seasonings for cooking the meat.

Display Name:
Ashley Mackie
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2542400.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tweaked this recipe just a little bit, and it came out AMAZING! I followed everything accordingly, as far as quantities goes with the root beer, BBQ sauce and tenderloin, however, I cut up the tenderloin into 3/4 inch chops, pierced them with a fork, enabling the juices to get soaked up; then seasoned chops with kosher salt, cracked pepper and a little bit of garlic powder. I then let it slow cook in the crock pot for 5 & 1/5 hours, drained the crock pot, set the chops out to cool for a few moments and pulled them apart (don't be discouraged, they appear to be a little tough at first). Once most of them are pulled I placed back into the crock pot and emptied the entire bottle of bbq sauce and added about 2 oz of more root beer in the bbq bottle to get the remainder of the sauce out, and cooked for an additional hour an half. Throughout the hour and half I was periodically pulling apart the chops with two forks at a time for more of a shredded affect. I used Stubbs bbq, for a gluten free pulled pork recipe. Hope y'all enjoy!
Review:

text:
I tired the recipe tonight to surprise my fiancé (since I had the day off, I spent the entire day baking his favorite cookies and wanted him to come home to a nice dinner!). The suggestions to poke the pork with a fork while it simmers was helpful. I also used some Jack Stack meat rub on it as well. It helped keep it moist. (I had 2 loins in the crockpot; 1 was forked and the other was not. The forked pork was MUCH more moist!)

I used a combo of KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce and Sweet Baby Rays (both were on hand). The sandwich was juicy and tasty. Fiancé liked it and asked for a repeat. I would like to see what other recipes are out there to give it some more "oomph", this seemed very safe. Overall, good recipe.

country:
None
text:
I have made this a few times now, and we have perfected it - we think.    I thinly slice, then halve an onion and put it in the bottom of the crock pot.   Then I plop the pork on top of the onion, then give it two good cranks of cracked black pepper.  Pour the root beer on (we use Hansen's - of all the ones we've tried, it's the best flavor with this) and let it go.   We use Stubbs BBQ sauce - - really like the flavor, and it's about the only one with no High Fructose Corn Syrup.

text:
Amazing!! I cooked a 3lb pork-loin for 6 1/2 hours in the root-beer, took it out 'pulled' it apart (really it mostly just shredded itself) put it back in the crockpot for another 1 hour with BBQ sauce and one yellow onion diced - the only thing i chewed in this sandwich was the bun, the pork melted in my mouth. Absolutely a keeper recipe! My x-husband loved it, as well as my 2 toddler kids, myself and my teenage brother.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness this was great. Served it last night when some friends came over for Monday Night Football. I used a 4lb Pork Shoulder as someone suggested and a 2L bottle of Rootbeer. Cooked on low for 7 hours. Drained and pulled apart, removing any fat I could. Added 1 bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory and Brown Sugar BBQ sauce and let sit on low for another hour. 1 bottle was just enough, so if you like it saucy I would recommend 1.5 bottles. With this BBQ sauce it is a little sweet, so maybe choose a different BBQ sauce if you like it more smokey. Buttered split buns and browned under the broiler, then topped with pulled pork and French's Fried Onions (as per another reviewers suggestion). Could not have been better!  All of us were rushing for seconds!!

text:
4 stars with the recipe as is....5 stars with these simple changes. I sear off each side of the roast in canola oil on the stove before putting it in the crockpot. Just 3 or 4 minutes on each side. I've found this helps the roast stay juicy and moist. 

I also leave the roast in with the bbq sauce for at least 30 minutes before serving, to give the flavors a chance to blend together. Top with a simple slaw and this makes a mean sandwich!

text:
After making this recipe with shoulder for years [trimming, degreasing and still having fatty bits on the finished product], I decided to try a 4 lb Single Pork Loin [not tenderloin] for a small gathering. The finished product had a very thin layer of fat on the surface, it was moist and super tender throughout!
4 lbs of meat, 2 1/2 cans of root beer and 1-40 oz Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ Sauce is THE BOMB for 17 people YES 17 large sandwiches! Wait for pork to go on sale and try it, my piece was only $13.

text:
I was a little concerned about cooking pork tenderloin in root beer all day but decided to give it a try based on the amazing reviews this recipe has received here. It was super easy to prepare and the meat was so tender it fell apart on it's own.  
Unfortunately my husband and I both felt we could taste the root beer. Overall the pork was too sweet for our taste, maybe because we're from SC and  are accustomed to a vinegar based barbecue. Probably just a personal preference.

text:
I made this recipe tonight, with a few tweeks from others who reviewed this recipe... I did a dry rub of garlic powder, black pepper, montreal steak seasoning and a pork rub.  I also used about 18 oz of A&W root beer...because I had 2 and a half pounds of tenderloin cooked it for 5 1/2 hours turned it half way through...drained it then shredded it and used one and a half bottles for sweet baby rays sweet and spicy BBQ sauce and cooked for another hour..stirring half way through. It came out FANTASTIC!!! We had it on fresh sandwich rolls from the bakery and I made a homemade cole slaw to go with it. It truly is simple and easy and deserves 10 stars..

Ok, so same day....I just got done eating this for dinner....OUTSTANDING! Thank you so much Livvie's Mammy for sharing this recipe! It is by far better than any other we have tried, and this will be the recipe we use from now on. This is a great dinner to make when it is 93* out with the air off. The pork was extremely tender and I used sweet baby ray's bbq sauce, my favorite for anything, and only ate it with potato chips, the salty of the chips complimented the sweetness of the pulled pork. Thanks again!!
One last thing........it only took 5 hours in the crock pot!

We had this tonight - it was terrific and super easy. I made it per recipe, though I only had diet rootbeer in the house, which didn't seem to make a difference. Served it with sauce on the side - we used and love Stubbs Original BBQ sauce. Will definitely make this easy peasy crowd pleaser again!

This was AMAZING!!! I used pork butt and added a whole head of crushed garlic and 1 large onion quartered along with some salt. I used 1 liter from a 2 litter bottle of A&W root beer. Cooked it for 8 hrs and then removed the pork to shred. I cleaned the slow cooker and put in the shredded pork with a whole bottle of Famous Dave's sweet and sassy bbq sauce.  This was perfect and super easy. This is my new bbq pulled pork recipe! Thank you for sharing :)

text:
I love bbq and was very doubtful about this recipe but with so many good reviews, I thought I'd try it.  Oh, boy. It was excellent!  As good as my favorite bbq restaurant at a fraction of the price. I used pork shoulder and it was perfect. When I make it again I will change one thing. Instead of draining and shredding it at 7 hours and then finishing it in bbq sauce for the last hour, I will pull it out of the root beer at 7 hours, shred it, and return it to the hot root beer until ready to serve. Then I would drain it and let people put on their own sauce.  It's not so sweet that way.  Thanks for the recipe. No leftovers here!

I followed the recipe exactly, used fresh, unopened, high quality root beer, but there was no flavor but stale root beer and it permeated the entire loin. text:
I used 2# pork tenderloin (wasn't dry at all, but a cheaper cut should work too). 

Before I put the meat in the slow cooker, I covered it on all sides with salt, pepper, garlic powder & chili powder.  

I used a 20 oz bottle of root-beer (it covered 3/4 of the meat, so I flipped the meat after 3hours).  After 6 hours I drained the meat and it fell apart.  

I finished it off with Sweet Baby Rays Sweet & Spicy BBQ sauce.  So good!  I will be making this again.

country:
None
text:
I have made this several times and my picky family loves it!  I have never tasted the "root beer" taste that some people claim to have tasted.  You could easily substitute coke and get the same effect.  Why it works is because soda is an acid and it acts as a tenderizer.  Also, any cut of pork would work.  It doesn't have to be a tenderloin.  What really makes or breaks this recipe is the type of BBQ sauce you use.  Don't buy a cheap low end sauce.  This is not the place to skimp.  Enjoy!

text:
This was very good! I used a 2.5 lb pork shoulder and 2 cans of A&W root beer. I cooked it on low for 7 hours, drained it, shredded it, and added Sweet Baby Ray's Honey bbq sauce and cooked another 1 hour. Next time I will start cooking it a couple hours earlier because it wasn't "fall of the bone" tender. I had a hard time shredding it but I didn't want to wait any longer to eat! It was still SO good! I couldn't taste any root beer either. I can't wait for leftovers tonight!!

text:
This was ridiculously easy, and tasted disproportionately delicious considering the little work involved!  I cooked mine for 6 hours on low in the root beer, then drained it, added some sauteed onions and then the BBQ sauce (make sure you use a good flavorful brand, not the cheap-o stuff), and cooked for another 2 hours.  This was fantastic.  The only thing I'll do different next time is to rub the meat with salt and pepper prior to cooking, because I found that it needed salt at the end.  Thanks for this recipe!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2011-09-25T16:22:43.39
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
6256916
Display Name:
HealthyMama
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
19
favoritesCount:
41
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great. When I cook for my immediate family, I use pork tenderloin, but when I cooked for 25 people, I used a pork shoulder and cut off the fat. Much cheaper! I used Pepsi, instead of Root Beer, because it's what I had on hand. I cooked in a slow cooker the day before the party, and let it cook some more the next day with water in the bottom, to keep it moist. Then pulled it apart  and added the barbecue sauce. Let it cook until we were ready to eat and it turned out great.  This is a great meal for those on a budget. I paid $25 for a large shoulder roast and it could of fed my immediate family 15 to 20 times. The one thing I would of done differently, is I wish I had separate a third of it out, before adding the sauce, so people that didn't want the sauce on, could have it plain. That would work good, if you wanted to add it to other recipes too!  After feeding 25 people one day and another 15 the second day, we were still able to freeze 2 large gallon size bags of pulled pork. Great recipe!

After reading previous reviews.  I added sea salt & fresh ground pepper to the crock pot.  I also opted for a spicy bbq sauce.  I believe that the spicy bbq is imperative for the recipe since the root beer is so sweet.  This recipe is AWESOME!  Fast, Easy, & Delicious!

text:
This was AWESOME!  Used pork roast with A&W Root Beer.  Cooked on low for 4-1/2 hours, then high for 1/2 hour.  Removed from crockpot and "pulled" the pork, adding Cattleman's BBQ sauce when I was done.  Returned to the slow cooker for about 30 min.  Served with my favorite cole slaw from this site (Restaurant-Style Coleslaw I) YUM! and a fresh fruit salad and BBQ beans.  The meal was absolutely delicious, and my Hubby and son both agreed it was the best pulled pork sandwich they'd ever eaten.  Thanks, Livie's Mammy, this one is in our dinner rotation for GOOD!

text:
Planned on making this with pork shoulder as other reviewers had, but tenderloin happened to be on sale - and for the small portion i was making it actually ended up being cheaper.  Cooked this on low for 7 hours in my crock pot. Drained it, then shredded it very easily and added a generous amount Cattle Boyz bbq sauce, cooked on low for another hour.  Bringing this on a camping trip this weekend, i'm sure it will be a hit - easiest and best pulled pork i have made yet.

text:
I have made this recipe a few times - I am now editing a previous review.  Originally I thought it was flavorless, but I have found that this recipe is only as good as the root beer you use.  When I use basic grocery store root beer, not good.  When I use a "fancy," more flavorful kind available by the 6 pack, delish.  Many compliments at potlucks and people asking for the recipe. I use a 3-5 lb. pork butt instead of tenderloin.

Display Name:
Shannon

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did it a little different: 
Sauté onions and garlic with a tbsp of Olive Oil. Then I fork the pork (lol) and do a salt, pepper and minced garlic rub. I place it in the pot and pour 12 oz of sugar cane root beer over it and a tbsp of liquid smoke. Let that simmer for 5-6 hours. Note: I use a stoke pot with a cover on the stove top at a very low heat. I can not find a crock pot not made in Chine but it calls for a crock pot. 
After 5-6 hours I drain the root beer and fork the meat, pour 12-16 ounce of BBQ sauce, stir and simmer for 1-2 more hours. It is sweet but delicious. Serve it on buns with any condiments you enjoy such as BBQ sauce, coleslaw, onions, lettuce and tomatoes. And don’t forget the yummy sides! My Daughter said I could sell this, it is her new favorite.

text:
My family loved it. I made a 4 pound pork roast fried each side before placing it into slow cooker, I used 1 cans of root beer after about 4 hours I added one  onion, red pepper and green pepper to it..  After a few hour I tried it and thought no way did I add the peppers, it tasted like peppers alot,  so I added another can of root beer and let it cook a few more hours, added a bottle of bbq sauce u have to eye ball it don't want it to wet.  let that cook a bit longer.  OMG it was the best pulled pork I have ever had, u couldn't taste the peppers anymore it was sweet and delicious, my kids and husband loved it.. I did cook my pulled pork for around 15 hours on low.

text:
This was fantastic!  It was such a hit that I actually made it twice this week  :)  I agree with the reviews that say to use a cheaper cut of meat.  The first time I used a 2 lbs. tenderloin b/c that's what I had ($14 worth of meat) and a thick and spicy bbq sauce.  The second time I used a 3.5 lbs. roast ($7 on sale) and a hickory sauce.  The roast was just as tender and pulled apart just as easily.  Once I shredded the meat I added the sauce and put it back in the pot on low until my husband came home.  This will be a regular meal and a definite party food from now on!

text:
I don't know what I did wrong but this didn't turn out very well. I cooked it on low for 6 hours and it was pretty dry. I had to pull the meat apart by hand.  I wonder if the thermometer on the crock pot is off because I can't imagine that I cooked it too long. I had a 6 lb pork roast. It was very tough :(

Edited to add that I have learned that most times when a cut of meat like this still remains tough, then it has not had enough time to tenderize-it can take 8-10 hours, so if your meat is tough, keep cooking it! Other than chicken, most meats will eventually fall apart if you keep cooking them.

text:
Oh My Word ~ ~ ~  yummy!  I made this with an 8lb pork shoulder as suggested in some of the reviews, filled it with Root Beer just to the top of the roast and cooked it for 10 hours on low.  I shredded it (so easily). Then divided it in half and doused with Famous Dave's Rich and Sassy BBQ sauce, then saved it in the fridge until the next day. Each Fri, the 2nd shift guys where my hubby works,  take turns bringing dinner in for the 4 man crew. As it was Hubby's turn, I sent the pork, extra sauce, buns, coleslaw and chips. Had Hubby put it in their crock pot 2 hrs before serving, on low,,,, they LOVED it! One poor guy ate 4 sandwiches and was miserable the rest of the night,,, but asked to take the leftovers home, HA!

text:
Followed the instructions and was not happy with results at all. Really bland. However, it appears that the type of bbq sauce used completely makes the difference. When I originally made it, I used a mustard based bbq sauce, as I'm not partial to the standard ones. When reheating the next day, I used a regular bbq sauce and it was great. I give the recipe 5 stars but feel a notation should be made about the type of bbq sauce so others don't make my mistake. :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used Picnic Roast as this was all the market had left of cheap pork. Added powdered onion and garlic with the Root beer. On low for 6 hrs, pulled from slow cooker and pulled apart. When adding back in to slow cooker, I layered it. Some BBQ with a dusting of onion and garlic powder along with 6 dash of Hot sauce, layer of pulled port, layer of BBQ, onion and garlic powder than last layer of pulled pork. Topped it off with dusting of onion and garlic powder, 6 more dashed of Hot sauce and a bit more BBQ. Folded in pot until well mixed and slow cooked it another hour. Never had better Pulled Pork BBQ!

text:
Love the idea of slow cooker pulled pork, but don't notice the root beer added much to the meat's flavor.  It was very tender so perhaps the use of root beer its more for the acids in the soda, but perhaps another form of moisture would result in more flavor.  Used a pork shoulder cut and after slow cooking for seven hours low, pulling it, mixed it with BBQ sauce, and put it back in the slow cooker for another hour.  Always pick up local BBQ sauces when traveling, so plan on slow cooking pork again with another sauce.

I shredded the pork when it was cooked, and cooked it about another hour with the bbq sauce. This was a fine recipe, but can definitely get better bbq by going out!!

Not real sure why I added a can of root beer to this?   Also not sure why this recipe gets such rave reviews?  The texture was mushy, flavor was non-existant until I added my barbecue sauce, upon which it just tasted like my barbecue sauce.  I could just salt & pepper my pork, add a tad bit of water, and slow cook it, add my barbecue sauce & get the same results, without having mushy pork.   We topped it with pickles & onions to give it some "ooomph".

So easy and delicious.  I was skeptical at first because it did not smell great but once I stirred the bbq sauce in it smelled amazing.  Definitely a keeper.  Tastes even better the second day.  I would recommend using a pork loin as other reviewers said as it is MUCH cheaper.  We shredded the pork about 5.5 hours in and let it sit in the root beer for about half an hour before adding the BBQ sauce and then let that sit for another half hour to let everything marry.  perfect!

text:
Wow.  This was so simple to make and the leftovers were great.  I followed the recipe only adding a couple of things.  Rubbed garlic salt and pepper on it. I then poke holes in the meat to better flavor the meat.  Placed thick slices of onions on the bottom of slow cooker and placed meat on top of the onions.  Added the root beer and let it cook on low for 6 hours.  Shredded the pork and chopped the onions.  Mixed both with BBQ sauce and continue to cook on warm for another hour to blend the flavors.

text:
Easy, easy, easy, that is the best way to describe this recipe. Using pork shoulder is the way to go. It is cheap and does not dry out when cooked for several hours. The smoke flavor is not there and it is a little mushy instead of having a sturdier texture,but that does not take away from it being a good easy way to make BBQ for a crowd.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
In my opinion this recipe was an awesome starting point and idea for making the pork tender and tasty. I did use a different cut of pork and seasoned the pork with S&P, Paprika, Cumin, crushed red peppers, a pinch of red curry seasoning, half an onion cut up, and made 7-8 cuts in the meat and filled with a bit of garlic then put in 16oz of A&W Rootbeer. After ithe meat cooked on low for 8 hours I drained a good majority of the liquid and then added Masterpiece Spicy BBQ sauce to cook for another hour or so. House smelled sooooo good that whole day and tasted even better the next day for lunch. Once again, awesome recipe!

text:
This recipe is about as easy as it gets! I used a ~4lb. pork shoulder and 2 cans of Hansen's root beer.  The root beer added just the right amount of sweetness to the pork without being overpowering (I was worried about this given I'd never cooked with soda!). Unlike an earlier review, I had no problem with the soda sticking to the sides of the crockpot. Extremely easy clean-up.  Super tasting!

text:
I tried this receipe while camping.  Needed something for a crockpot potluck.  Had a different meal planned, but wanted something easier.  Used a pork shoulder (2 of them, 1 at 6 lbs, 1 at 7lbs.)  Used 1 1/2 bottles of root beer each.  Cooked for approx 7 1/2 hrs.  Drained & covered in Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce.  Smaller one was ready first.  It was a HUGE HIT!!  Had the other one for leftovers the next day and for dinner when we got home on Monday.  We all loved it!!

I used A&W root beer and Sweet Baby Rays BBQ Sauce. We top ours with coleslaw, but thats a family thing :) It's really simple, incredibly tasty and fool proof. TRY IT!

Delicious and so easy!  I used a pork shoulder and cut off the fat before putting into the slow cooker.  Meat was so tender and easy to shred.  Used Sweet Baby Ray's Sweet and Spicy BBQ sauce. Easiest dinner I've made in a long time...will definitely make it again!

AMAZING! Best pulled pork ever! It was so easy my kids could have made it! I used a 4lb Boston butt because it cheaper and more. Cooked it overnight w/ rootbeer, shredded it in the morning, added some Sugar Ray's Brown Sugar n Hickey BBQ sauce, slow cooked it for another hr and BAMM - lunch and dinner! My family loved it! We made sandwiches and even used the meat on nachos.

text:
Was very good as well as easy. I as one review said used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce but I used the sweet and spicy and it was good. I also as one review said, thought it would be hard to clean the crockpot but it cleaned up easily and I did not spray it with cooking spray, I used a  salt and pepper rub on the meat before cooking and I did use a little bit more than 12 oz of rootbeer.  I also sprinkled some meat tenderizer on the meat while it was cooking. I will be making this again for the family reunion in another week.

text:
This recipe was WONDERFUL and so easy! I had a pork tenderloin in the freezer and I thawed it in the fridge the night before. In the morning, I pulled out the porkand rubbed it with salt, pepper and garlic salt. Since it was a very long cut, I divided it up into about four pieces roughly the same size. Poked some holes in the meal, threw it into the crockpot and let it go all afternoon!  It was so easy and I loved it. I used Jack Daniels Spicy BBQ sauce and the taste was phenomenal! Everyone was RAVING about it. I will definitely make this again :D

After seeing how many reviews this pulled pork got I was excited to try it. But, as you can tell by the recipe it is very simple so at best I have to say it's an average recipe. Did people at the party like it? Yes. Was it easy? Yes. For those reasons, I think this pulled pork recipe is great for someone who just wants a standard, easy pulled pork. text:
I made this on Sunday for my husband's birthday and it got rave reviews from the crowd of 15!  I seasoned and trimmed the fat from two 4 lb pork rump roasts and put them in the crock pot with 4 cans or root beer and cooked on high for 4 hours.  When I got home over 5 hours later, I had a hard time getting the 4 pounder out of the crock pot because it was falling apart.  After shredding the meat I added 1/2 bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Chipotle BBQ sauce and 1/2 bottle of their Hickory Brown sugar and returned the meat to the crock pot and put on warm. Delicious!

Really good and extremely easy.  I put this on at 9 at night in a slow cooker with a warm setting.  I cooked it on low for 7 hours and didn't think about it again until about 10:30. text:
Never thought I'd enjoy pork soaked in root beer until I tried this. So incredibly easy to make and the pork falls off the fork. I did 'spice' it up a bit before I put the root beer in. I rubbed with kosher salt and fresh gound pepper front and back, then added minced garlic and rubbed. I'll admit the smell of root beer and garlic cooking is not the best, but the taste is AMAZING. Used Chris and Pitts BBQ sauce and was licking my fingers after seconds! Will make several times. Also, grocery store did not have tenderloin (honestly), so I used pork shoulder.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used a 4 lb shoulder, 4 cans of root beer, one can of water, and rubbed the shoulder with seasonings before I put it in th slow cooker. The meat was almost covered completely. I let it  cook for 10 hours and when I got home it was ready to go. I drained it, reserved about a cup of the liquid to put in with the sauce, shredded it and put in some Stubb's original sauce (I'm a Texas girl) and the broth. The result was crazy, tender, awesome goodness that rivals any restaurant pulled pork I've ever had. I will use this recipe again and again and again. The un-sauced meat was not super sweet, it was super moist and just plain wonderful. I made again the same way with tenderloin (for 10 hours) and it wasn't stringy or tough at all. I'll do it with this cut from now on to save on fat and calories.

text:
I used a pork shoulder and 1 can of root beer, cooking on low in the slow cooker for 7 hours and then attempting to shred, but I think that it could have cooked a lot longer (we were pressed for time so we couldn't wait). I had to slice the meat as it didn't come out too tender, then put it in a casserole dish with the bbq sauce and cooked on 350° for 30 minutes or so. The flavour was great but the tenderness wasn't quite there. Next time I will take the advice of others here and cover the meat with root beer, cooking for about 10 hours on low, and then try the shredding. Easy recipe, just needed longer with a shoulder!

text:
I have a recipe for rootbeer pulled pork that is similar (not sure if it came from this site!).  But the pork cooks in JUST the rootbeer with a sliced onion, some garlic and salt & pepper.  When the pork is done, you simmer 2 cans of root beer with a jar of chili sauce until it reduces and put that over your pork.  AMAZING!  I guess you could cook it all together, but the nice, thick sauce is wonderful.

I seasoned the pork with some salt, pepper, and chili powder before adding to the crock pot. Also, I used a pork butt rather than tenderloin. text:
This was a really good recipe.  I made it last night for my husband and youngest son and they devoured it, even though my husband doesn't like anything with BBQ sauce in it.  I was skeptical of making anything in a crock pot since usually everything tastes the same, but this recipe was definitely the exception.  I cooked the pork tenderloin for 8 hours, turning about every hour or so, then drained, shredded and returned to the pot with Sweet Baby Rays Honey BBQ Sauce for another hour with just a bit of water added to keep it from drying out.  Served on very soft hamburger buns for a great meal.  Next time, I might try toasting the buns so they don't get so soggy.  Thanks so much for sharing, Livie's Mammy!
Review:
Rating:

This was a winner! I asked the butcher which cut I should use and the package sis not say but it was a big chunk with no fat. I cut it in half and cooked them for 4-5 hours on high since I was short on time and it was awesome if I don't say so myself.  What I did differently: - I added Coca Cola instead of root beer.  - I also added a few fresh garlic cloves (smashed but still in one piece so I could fish them out when the pork was done) - Added a few chopped green onions  I can't wait to make this again!

text:
I tried this a couple of days ago on a pork roast I needed to use up in the freezer.  It was the BEST pulled pork I've ever made!  I did sprinkle some garlic powder and paprika on top of the pork before I closed the lid.  I know one other reviewer mentioned that the part that wasn't covered with root beer was kind of dry, and I found that to be the case too.  Next time I will completely submerge the pork in root beer.  It was falling apart, extremely moist, and delicious. This will definitely be the only way I make pulled pork in the future.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 3lb pork tenderloin, put 1/4 sweet onion & sm bell pepper 2 sm garlic cloves chopped. Sprinkle pork with barbecue seasoning and then placed overtop of veg. Pour 12oz beer over and pour 1/4 of bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's sauce on pork, on low for 4hrs. Drained juices put veg & pork back in along with remaining sauce plus another half a both and cook on med another 1hr. Pork was very tender but too sweet. Next time I'll either use spicier sauce or leave plain & add whatever sauce guest want.

text:
The flavour of this pork was pretty good (but how can you go wrong with bottled bbq sauce!), and none of the root beer flavour came through.  The reason I gave this dish only 2 stars is that the texture of the pork tenderloin after shredding was completely mushy...this cut of meat was so tender that it had absolutely no texture to it whatsoever.  I may make this again, but will definitely use a cheaper, sturdier cut of meat.

None
country:
None
text:
I seasoned the pork with salt, pepper, and garlic powder, then stab it with a fork a few times, as suggested by another commentor.  Since I didn't have a slow cooker, I put it in my oven at 170 for 6.5 hours. (I would suggest going up to 200, since the pork still didn't shred easily)  Shred the pork best I could, added enough BBQ sauce to coat it, and put it back in for an hour.  Took it out and coated it again to serve it.  And yes, it tastes even better the next day!

text:
After eight hours on low, I removed the pork to drain off the fat and root beer (I used a 20 oz. bottle) and to shred it. I almost left it at that because it was so delicious! But dinnertime was still two hours away, and I didn't want it to dry out, so I returned it to the crockpot on low and added a 28 oz. bottle of KC Masterpiece Original barbecue sauce. WOW! This is amazingly good and so easy - I'm sure I'll make it again! Thanks for the recipe!

I made this for a family gathering. I had a pork shoulder already so I used that instead of a tenderloin. text:
I made this for a couples game night and our guests couldn't believe this wasn't from a local BBQ restaurant. I used a Boston Butt Roast, poked holes in it and sprinkled it generously with seasoned tenderizer on all sides. I poured a 2 liter bottle of A&W Root Beer over the roast and cooked on low for 8 hours. I used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce. The roast was so tender, I barely needed to shred it! I will be making this again!

text:
Simple and easy recipe for pulled pork.  I did make a few changes, however.  First, I used a much cheaper cut, no need to use an expensive piece of meat. My pork roast was approximately 4 pounds. I filled the slow cooker with A & W Root Beer to about half way up the roast and added minced garlic for addtional flavor. Cooked on low for 10 hours, then shredded. Served on lightly toasted buns and topped with shredded Cheddar cheese. Yummy!!

text:
I combined this recipe with the Southern Pulled Pork and ideas of my own to come up with top notch pulled pork. I added the onions, liquid smoke, and garlic from the Southern recipe then was set to add the root beer to the liquid and realized all I had was diet so I added cream soda instead. It cooked for 7 hrs on high then I poured all of it into a strainer and pulled the pork in the strainer, it just fell apart. Then I put all of it back in the slow cooker and added just enough BBQ sauce to keep it moist and cooked for another hour then served on kaiser rolls. Marvelous.

The sauce you choose will really make a huge difference.

text:
This was very tasty!! I too used a pork roast instead of loin b/c it was much cheaper. And the meat turned out juicy and tender. Because I enjoy the flavor of the meat I didn't simmer in BBQ like some other reviewers did. (also b/c I didn't have time!!) Instead I mixed some of the juices from the roast, bbq sauce, ketchup, brown sugar, s&p, onion powder and garlic salt in a sauce pan and poured over the meat.  This way you get the great flavor of the meat, but also some of that sweet and tangy sauce! Thanks for the recipe!

This was such an easy way to make pulled pork!!  I will say I prefer to use pork loin for other recipes, for this I bought a huge pork shoulder at costco. :)  I ended up using a 6+ lb portion, 3 cans diet rootbeer (didn't feel the need for extra sugar) and cooked in my crockpot on High for about 5.5-6 hours.  If I had known how long it would take to pull the pork- I would have left a LOT more time before dinner.   We put this on the Hamburger Buns recipe from this site, and boy was it tasty!  Turned out perfect, and we have enough leftovers for 1-2 more dinners!  THANKS!

text:
I like that it is easy to make.  The taste was a little bland.  I made some cole slaw and it made it much better. I really think the key is the type of BBQ sauce you use. I used a traditional sauce and wished I had used a spicy or sweet one.   You can not taste the root beer at all, so really all you will taste is the sauce.  The pork was VERY tender.   I will make again and use a different sauce!

text:
I am rating this 4 stars because my husband and brother-in-law loved it, and I am not a huge fan of BBQ - so not the best judge for this one. :) It was very easy to make. I placed the 3 lb shoulder roast roast on thick sliced onions and added three peeled cloves of garlic. We used A&W root beer and cooked on low for 3 hours. The meat was very tender and tasty. We added Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce. I will definitely make this again, I'll probably just put some aside sans sauce for me next time.

text:
I loved this recipe! I did do a few things to change it though.  I used a boston butt instead of a tenderloin.  I rubbed it withsalt, pepper and montreal seasoning and then added onion, and garlic to the slow cooker.  I used about 4 cans of diet root beer, enough to cover the meat. I cooked it about 3 hours on high and 2 on low and then pulled it apart and then as suggested by others added sweet baby rays sweet and spicy sauce and simmered for about an hour! It was so yummy. Definatly a keeper!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was easy and great!  I used pork butt instead of tenderloin; in a slow cooker the meat cooks for so long that you can use a less premium cut of meat and still end up with very tender and moist meat.  Also the carbination on the soda helps tenderize the meat.  The pork butt turned out great for a fraction of the cost.  Shred the pork when its warm - I cut it into chucnks and cooked this overnight because I didn't want to overcook it (pork can get gummy and rubbery when cooked for more than 8 hours in a slow cooker).  I refrigerated it while I was at work and it was difficult to shred when it was cold.  I would also suggest using 3-4 pounds of meat and doubling the rest of the ingredients.  This makes pretty small servings otherwise.  Overall, a very easy and inexpensive meal!

text:
Very easy and tasted great! I slow cooked the pork on low for about 5 hours, drained and shredded it, and then put it back in the slow cooker, and added Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory BBQ sauce, turned the cooker down to "keep warm" until dinner (about an hour) I've never done this before, and had no idea how to "pull" pork, so I read some things online and took two forks and just ripped the meat - by the time it came for pulling, the meat was so loose and tender - it was very easy. Great recipe, thanks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a vegetarian, so I have to base my reviews on my husband's taste.  As far as the flavor, he gave it 5 stars!  We used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and he loved it.  The problem he had was in the texture.  I don't know if there's a better way to shred it (mine just fell apart on its own), but it was too fine and stringy.  He referred to it as "cat food".  I thought it looked like something worse, but I'll spare you.  Perhaps a different cut of meat would give you a thicker shred.  If you're used to a stringy pulled pork, this recipe is super easy and delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was quite tasty! Although Im sure you could probably get away with a cheaper cut of pork, the tenderloin was awfully good. The rootbeer was an unexpected ingredient but it worked really well. For the people who commented on the sweetness, I think that their complaint might be due to the use of a sweet sauce.  We live in the south where we use a vinegar based sauce, so I did not have that problem at all. I recommend Johnny Harris sauce from Savannah, GA if its available in your area. I also salted and peppered the pork before adding the rootbeer, and I think that helped in the end result. Altogether a simple and yummy way to cook BBQ.

text:
I was afraid that root beer might make this too sweet for me, so I used a bottle of Corona and Montgomery Inn barbecue sauce.  Turned out very good.  But the best part for me was the gravy that I made from the juices.  Don't throw out the juice!  Whisk it into a roux and it makes a VERY tasty gravy (using Corona, anyway).  I don't know how the gravy would be if i had started with root beer.

country:
None
text:
I made this recently for a barbecue and I'm glad to say that everyone loved it.  The modifications I made were this:  I used turkey london broil instead of pork; I also cut up an onion, put Chicken Rub on both sides of turkey, stabbed it a few times with a knife, and sealed it in a plastic bag overnight.  Like another reviewer, I also added some b-b-q sauce to the root beer.  At the end of the cooking time, after draining the meat, I added the rest of the b-b-q sauce and continued cooking in the crock pot on low for at least another hour. The shredded turkey meat turned out very flavorful and very tender, and I definitely plan to make this again and again.

This is a great recipe.  I used a different cut of pork but it still worked out fabulous.  The only thing I did a little different was leave some of the juice in the mixture and then added the barbeque sauce and let it cook on high for about an hour stirring occasionally.  I turned the heat off and let it sit for awhile so the barbeque sauce would cook into the meat more.  I'll turn it back on about an hour before serving this evening and I'm sure it'll be a hit!

text:
Thank you for this awesome recipe!  It was so simple and easy.  I was throwing a huge BBQ party for my husband's birthday, but didn't want to do any major cooking.  I used a pork rub on the 4 lbs. of tenderloin, put in the slow cooker and went about my day stress-free.  After about 6 hours, it came out perfect.  The pork shredded so easily.  The day of the party, I split it into two batches, using two different BBQ sauce (one hot and spicy, the other sweet and tangy).  I put each batch in a slow cookers, mixed the BBQ (an hour before the party) and it was hot and ready to be served once the party started.  So easy!

None
text:
I have made this recipe twice now, and it's  very easy and turns out great.
 
 I make it with two pork Tenderloins, as they typically come in at around 1.2 pounds each.

 I  questioned using Pork Tenderloin vs Pork Shoulder but was  very pleasantly surprised with the end product. It is exceptionally lean, and after 7 or 8 hours on Low it shreds very easily.
 This is about as easy as it gets for a tasty comfort food meal the whole family loves.

 We use Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory Brown Sugar sauce with it, but I know sauces are a very personal thing.

  We usually  make nachos with chips, cheese and some sour cream on them, but it also makes a great sandwich or taco too !

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a pork shoulder roast. I believe the fat content with this cut keeps the pork very moist. I entirely covered the meat with a and w root beer and left to cook for 10 hours then drained. I shredded and added very little bbq sauce, and put it back on for another hour . I am not a big fan of having pulled pork where the only flavour is bbq sauce. This was a fantastic simple resipe. I sprayed the slow cooker with coconut spray twice and clean up was a breeze.Two very big thumbs up.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am trying all of the different styles of "pulled pork" (Sweet southern ‘Tennessee’ style Pulled Pork, Maple-Mustard East Coast Style Pulled Pork, high vinegar Carolina BBQ, Hawaiian Pulled Pork and Slow Cooker Carnitas) and this is the first. It is an EXCELLENT KEEPER!! Yes, it is sweet which has its place. I let the Crock Pot run over night and finished it in the morning. The only difference I made was to cut it down to a 2 1/2 pound, bone-in, pork shoulder roast and dumped in 16 oz of A&W Root-beer. It is really inexpensive such that the Sweet Baby Ray Sweet and Spicy sauce cost almost as much as the meat.

text:
This was so delicious! I used 3.6 lb. Boston Butt. I cooked it on high 7 hours, drained the root beer, shredded the pork, then added a bottle of Rumboggies Sweet Hickory BBQ sauce, and cooked on low 1 more hour. So amazing!  I usually just cook pulled pork like this but use a bottle of BBQ sauce only. The root beer will be the first ingredient from now on. I made homemade coleslaw and added it to my pulled pork sandwich on a hamburger bun.

text:
Very easy to make recipe and the pork came out very tender.  Will definitely do again.  The recipe says it takes about 8 hours, and I was worried because I forgot to defrost my meat before tossing it in .  I put it on the 10 hour setting to make up for it being frozen.  It was cooked in 8 hours anyway.  And this was enough to feed 8 people with leftovers.

userID:
3625215
Display Name:
Sandy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
62
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/816693.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so delicious.  I don't use a slow cooker that often as the food sometimes comes out a little dry.  Not this one!!  We were having a New Year's party so I used two 4lb. pork shoulder picnic roasts.  I covered the meat with 2L of A&W root beer and cooked it on high for about 4 hours then turned it down to low for another 2 hours.  After that I pulled out the roasts and drained all the root  beer.  We removed the bone & large pieces of fat, shredded the meat (it just fell apart), and mixed in  one and half bottles of Heinz Bold & Spicy BBQ sauce.  I let the meat slow cook on low for a couple more hours then added the last half bottle of BBQ sauce and onion flakes (for a bit of extra flavour) and turned the slow cooker to warm until everyone was ready to eat.  It was a big hit with everyone.  Hardly anything was left.  I will definitely be making this again.
Review:
Rating:
1
dateLastModified:
2018-12-30T19:39:59.8
helpfulCount:
0

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it, loved it.  However I also changed it.  Pork Tenderloin is just too lean to make this dish successful.  I used a traditional pork butt, about 4 lbs.  I added nothing to the recipe except the root beer it called for.  When it was done the house smelled really good.  When I took it out of the slow cooker, the bone fell away, the fat was easily removed and I had beautiful, beautiful and tasty meat in front of me.  I have one rule of thumb when it comes to cooking meat and that is, "FAT AND FLAVOR BOTH START WITH A 'F'".

Ok so here’s the deal - I made a bunch of changes to the recipe but kept the same idea. First, I used a pork butt since it was a whole lot cheaper for the amount I was making. I also ended up with a 7lb roast, but didn’t have to adjust the cook time. With the larger roast I used 2 bottles of root beer, then a larger bottle of sauce (same one previous reviewers used) and took the whole crockpot to work for a potluck. I came home with an empty crock and so many compliments! I’ll definitely be making this again!

text:
I've been making it this way for years, I just buy a bottle of regular root beer, usually A&W, pour it over the top almost to the top of the pot, plug it in and cook it on low for approximately seven hours it comes right off the bone. I buy a picnic roast,  drain it shred it ,add a little of your favorite bbq sauce, buy slider rolls and that's it! comes out consistently good every time.

I used half a 4 lb tenderloin and expected the meat to be a bit juicy and shred easily. It was dry and didn't shred easily so I believe there was a hiccup somewhere in my cooking. I cooked it in the root beer then drained it and added the barbecue sauce and meat back into the slow cooker. It was real good but I might cover the meat in root beer next time to see if that makes it any more juicy. Held up real nice in the fridge though, make some homemade mac and cheese and add this on top and you get a delicious meal.

userID:
15462007
Display Name:
Judy Goldthorp
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
29
favoritesCount:
76
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2120222.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will definitely make this again.  After reading the reviews, I used a 4 pound pork butt, seasoned it with Montreal Steak seasoning (salt & pepper would be fine), added 12 oz Root Beer (Kroger brand), and 1/2 cup apple cider vinegar.  i put  the crock in the refrigerator  for several hours.  Before I went to bed, I put the  crock in the crockpot and turned it on low.  When I got up this morning, the roast was just falling apart.  I  drained off the root beer, forked the pork apart and put  it back in the crock pot with a bottle of Kroger KC style BBQ sauce.  I kept it on warm all morning, until noon.  It was a big hit.  People had seconds!    Next time I will bring  those  King's Hawaiian dinner rolls or slider rolls.  That would have been a better sized roll than a hamburger bun (for our group)  Thanks for the great and very easy recipe!

And, no, it did not smell like root beer this morning when I pulled the meat apart.

6/7/2018  -- I made this for another pot luck.  This time I substituted beef broth (made with bouillon granules & water, because that's what I had on hand) for the root beer.  I still used the 1/2 cup apple cider vinegar.  I couldn't tell the difference in the taste between beef broth and root beer.  I think 12 oz of the liquid of your choice works.  It was a hit (again).  This is a very simple, but delicious thing to do with a pork roast.  Again I heard, "who brought the BBQ?"

text:
Amazing!  Doesn’t get easier than this - hardest part is remembering to put the thing in before you leave for work!  Any non-diet soda works if you don’t have root beer.  Ginger ale is great.  I tried 6 hrs on high with Ginger Ale and it came out amazing.  At the end I usually take it out, scrape off the fat, shred it just by pulling it apart on a plate with two large forks, drain the slow cooker, then put the shredded meat back in with about a cup of bbq sauce, mix well, and slow cook another 30 min on high.  Comes out so delicious.

This was a simple, yet delicious recipe. I followed every step and used a pork tenderloin that I found on sale for less than $4. The only thing that I did in addition to the prep as listed, which I do with most meat, was to season the pork with salt, pepper and a sprinkle of garlic powder, then placed in zip lock bags overnight.  My entire family enjoyed this and I will definitely make again.

I’ve made this a few times now and it’s certainly a Family favorite. The only reason I’m giving it 4 stars is because it asks for pork tenderloin, I find that if you use tenderloin it takes on way too much of the root beer flavor. I prefer a pork loin. country:
None
text:
This is so great! I made this about a month ago with 2lbs of pork tenderloin, and first rubbed it with salt, pepper and garlic then put it in with the root beer as well as a chopped onion. After cooking for 6-7 hours, I removed the meat and drained the slow cooker. I then shredded the meat, put it back in the slow cooker and added the BBQ sauce and warmed it on Warm mode for a little while until we were ready.

I'm making this again tonight with a 4lb pork shoulder, and using a can of beer instead of root beer (suggested by a friend) so we will see how that is!

text:
Excellent Simple Recipe. Tender,easy to shred,great taste.
I didn't have root beer and was so disappointed as I had bought a pork shoulder  really cheap on sale and found this recipe. I found a bottle of ginger beer I had ,so i used that. Also rubbed the pork shoulder with a onion soup mix packet and some garlic powder. Cooked on high 2 hrs,then low 4 hrs,drained all the fat off and cut up and shredded ,then poured over Uncle Rays BBQ sauce and cooked another 1hr on low.
So yummy ,could hardly wait to eat it. Served with a mashed sweet potato , pepper squash,and coleslaw.
Great dinner.

text:
I live this easy recipe. I used a 4lb pork roast. Kosher salt and pepper rub and injected it with chicken stock. Cooked on high heat to start and finished on low heat for 5 hours. Shredded the roast with Bear Claws and added two small bottles of Bulls Eye barbecue sauce, cooking on low for one more hour. It came out fantastic. Thank you AllRecipes.com (and several tips from reviewers).

text:
I love making this recipe in my VitaClay multi-cooker! It makes the beef so tender and juicy, and only takes 2-3 hours (depending on size). The texture and taste are great, but less so when I made it for longer hours in a different slow cooker. It seals up and holds all the juices in. So good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed things up just slightly - my local grocery store had an abundance of picnic roast at a great price so I picked one up. Put some salt pepper and garlic on one side of the roast(4lbs) and put 2 cups of a&w root beer in and then when my hubby got home around the 3 hour cooking mark he added another 2 cups - not sure if this made a difference or not but he always meddles in my cooking. After letting it cook on low for 6 hours I checked up on it and falling apart so I drained it and added 1 bottle of sweet baby rays and let it cook for another 1 hour on low. It tastes absolutely phenomenal. It didn't need the extra cooking time at all but after reading previous reviews I decided to give it a try. Melt in your mouth super yummy pulled pork. SO easy! Will definitely be volunteering to bring this dish over to any potlucks !!

text:
Definitely  quick to put together and easy!  We found it a little too sweet  and I raised the temperature to high for the last two hours since I planned on serving it in seven hours.  However, the next day the flavor was much improved as the barbeque sauce had a chance to settle in.  I would suggest making this the day before!

text:
brilliant, simple, delicious recipe. It is great as-is but there are so many possibilities to tweak it. I used a pork butt roast, rubbed it with salt, pepper, and garlic powder, and sauteed all that with no oil in the pressure cooker to give a bit of crispy coating. I then added a cup of chicken broth (actually 4 boullion cubes with a cup or so of water), and a bit of liquid smoke. The pressure cooker (Instant Pot in my case) gives the same tenderness in 2-3 hours. Just mix the sauce in at the end.

text:
Used pork tenderloin, 4.45 lbs. (we like pulled pork!) used Root Beer. Rubbed tenderloin with brown sugar, onion salt, other spices private recipe mixture. Cooked in slow cooker on LOW. Reserved all liquid to add back in: ended up using about half of it to keep pork moist. Meat pulled just fine after 7 hours of cooking in crock pot. Added splash of apple vinegar, half of reserved liquid and red pepper flakes and set out for dinner, with several types of sauce to choose from. I like vinegary, mustard sauces, hubby and son likes sweet and tangy BBQ sauces. Fix your plate, sauce the way you like it, and chow down! It was, and is, very very good. I made sure the meat was 90% submerged during cooking to retain moisture and that seemed to do the trick. Yes, it came out drier than when I use Butt or Shoulder, but the flavor is quite delicious. Would make again, exactly the same. Highly recommended.

text:
This is a great recipe!  I used 1/2 of a whole butt which weighed 4 lbs. so I used more root beer and put a dry rub on it, but those are the only changes.  Because of its size, it required a longer time in the crock pot.  It was my first pulled pork recipe I've ever used and I won't change a thing.  I do want to share with you though, that I was found an easy way to shred it.  If you have a standing mixer, use your normal paddle accessory, cut off chunks of the meat while still warm and start mixing on low.  Gradually increase the speed.  Within two minutes tops you have the best shredding job with no muss or fuss.

country:
