text:
Wow! This was good! And one of the easiest meals I've ever made! I followed the recipe except I used a 4lb shoulder rather than the pricey tenderloin. I slow cooked it with two bottles of root beer for 7 hours (rotating the meat about three times while it was cooking), drained it, shredded it with a fork (I easily took out the big pieces of fat at this point), put it back in the slow cooker with 2 cups of Sweet Baby Ray's original barbecue sauce and turned it on low for another hour before serving it. I must say that the first seven hours that the root beer and pork were simmering, I HATED how it smelled. Maybe that's just what pork smells like (I don't cook pork very often), but rest assured, the barbecue sauce makes the magic happen. I will definitely be making this again!!

text:
We made this recipe almost exactly as written.  We left the pork in longer than called for (10 hours, instead of 7), as it cooked overnight and we didn't get up early to finish cooking it.  

At 10 hours, after shredding the pork, we drained the liquid from the slow cooker and added "Trader Joe's Bold & Smoky Kansas City Style BBQ Sauce" to the shredded pork in the slow cooker.  We mixed in the sauce thoroughly, and then let the shredded pork cook on low another hour, to help incorporate the BBQ sauce.  It was delicious!

userID:
14235906
Display Name:
Nashen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
428
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4507945.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe- winner every time. The reason I'm knocking off a star is because I would never use a pork tenderloin for this. Use a shoulder or another cheaper cut- between cooking in soda and the long cook time, it will be just as tender, moist and juice. I usually use a good sized shoulder (can never find smaller ones) and use an entire 2 liter bottle of root beer. I dislike root beer, but the meat does not end up tasting like the drink after you drain the soda out. I usually use Sweet Baby Ray's Hot & Spicy (it's not really hot & spicy at all for my taste) BBQ sauce with a glug or two from another flavored BBQ sauce I have on hand or sometimes a little hot sauce. I serve this on hamburger buns with optional cheese and coleslaw. The slaw is a great addition to the sandwich- gives it a nice fresh crunch. Sometimes I'll also rub the shoulder with salt, pepper and any other on-hand spices like garlic power or onion powder before I drop it in the slow cooker. A good tip for mess-free cleanup (the sugary soda and BBQ sauce is a real hassle to scrub out of the slow cooker) is to use a plastic slow cooker liner. Once dinner is done and leftovers are packed, you just pull out the liner and toss in the garbage. Cleanup all done!

text:
Pretty good!  I used a 5 LB pork loin with one can of root beer, lots of onion powder & some liquid smoke in the crock pot...adding a little water until the meat was covered.  I cooked on low for 10 hours...nice texture, mild flavor, easily shredded without being mushy.  Added light amount of BBQ sauce (you can always add more according to flavor) and put thin layer of pork mixture on small baking sheet.  Baked at 400 for 10 minutes to crisp the BBQ up a little.  Kids ate it without complaints....froze the rest in small freezer bags for easy weeknight meals.

Michelle

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AMAZING! I only deviated from the recipe a little, taking the advice of a couple of reviewers. I used a 2 lb tenderloin and poked holes in it all over. Then, I rubbed fresh ground pepper, salt, garlic powder, and onion powder all over it. I put the meat in the slow cooker with 16 oz root beer and cooked on low for 7 hours, then drained the meat. I shredded the meat in the crock pot, poured about 28 oz of Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ Sauce over it, and cooked on low for another hour and served it on toasted butter buns. YUM! I was told by many that it was the best pulled pork they'd ever had! Word of advice...do NOT use a cheap BBQ sauce, like Kraft.

text:
I do not normally leave reviews but Holy oinker Batman! The grocery store I went to did not have unseasoned tenderloin so I used a 4# pork shoulder and prepared it as directed. For my sauce I used a nice smoky Hickory combined with Sweet Baby Ray's Honey and Sweet and Spicy (I had planned on only the hickory but it made so much I had to go to my BBQ meatballs reserve sauce). I used a 20 oz bottle of root beer which didn't completely cover the meat so I put it in the crockpot fat side up. I live alone so my plan was to eat some then freeze the rest. Ha! I ate it for breakfast (in omelets with roasted peppers and onions), lunch (on buns either hot or cold, sometimes Carolina style, sometimes not) and for dinner (sometimes on buns sometimes not, sometimes with peppers and sometimes with coleslaw). Once I was done eating nothing but pulled pork for days, I had to stop myself from making another one. I have never found a recipe that was so simple and yet so delicious.

text:
Delicious!  I used a Picnic Shoulder Butt, FAT SIDE UP, and then  discarded the excess fat before pulling the meat apart.
In my opinion, you ruin the meat when you put in all that BBQ sauce.  You also have no other option except BBQ when you do that.  I just added the garlic, salt and pepper ( and a little Cavender's Greek seasoning).  We had pork carnitas one night, BBQ nachos another night,  BBQ sandwiches another night, then pork tacos for lunch....so many different options if you don't douse it in the sauce.   You can always add the BBQ sauce later.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe! Very simple. With my slow cooker it only took 5 hours on low because I didn't want to dry out the meat. I would definitely recommend not using a whole bottle of BBQ sauce right off the bat when it comes time to pull apart the meat and mix it in. It can be a little much. I used about half a bottle to marinade the meat in and then added a little extra and mixed it in when serving. The pork has such a good flavor from cooking all day that I didn't want to mask it!! Definitely try this! :)

text:
Very easy and good. I used the Hand-mixer method to pull/shred the pork. What a massive time saver! My meat was shredded perfectly in less than 20 seconds. Where I live, there is no such thing as root beer, so I used a can of Coke. Any kind of pop (soda) will have the same effect - sweetness, and the acid for tenderizer. Root beer will add some "herb" flavor.

text:
Great recipe, many thanks! After reading reviews, added 1 Walla Walla sweet onio, chili flakes and 3-4 smashed garlic cloves.  Cooked on low for  7 hours then pulled pork. Added Fletchers BBQ sauce (made in Spokane, WA) and cooked on low for another 3 hours. Absolutely delish and in mid-August, a great way to keep the kitchen cool. Will definitely make again, cheers!

text:
Easy peasy.  Never would have guessed that cooking it in Root Beer would be a good idea.  It totally worked.  I made a 6 pound pork shoulder and added 2 bottles of  Virgil's Root Beer.  I cooked it overnight on low.  Started at 10:30pm and at 7:30am I drained it.  I probably drained it too much, frankly, but no matter.  I added about 2 cups chx stock and 2 bottles of  bbq sauce,  I put it on warm and low intermittently for the next few hours and it was just perfect.  Easiest thing I've ever made.

text:
6-8-2016  ~First, in my mind a pork shoulder roast is much better suited for this cooking method than is lean pork tenderloin.  And I wish I would have drunk the good Sprecher root beer I used for this.  While the pork was good, I can say it was not because of the root beer, which added nothing.  Cooking the roast as I usually do, about seven hours with little to no water, shredding the meat, then adding your favorite barbecue sauce to taste and cooking an hour or so more, is every bit as good, if not better – better because I could have enjoyed drinking that darned good root beer.

text:
Make sure you have enough BBQ sauce to cover your pork...otherwise some of it will be untouched (I learned that the hard way).  If you have left overs, put it in a bowl, cover the top with plastic wrap, and then leave it in your fridge until you're ready to serve again.  :)

text:
I did make some changes.
I used an almost 4 pound boneless pork shoulder. I cut it in half to get it to fit into my crockpot.  I made fork holes all over the pork and before cooking I rubbed it with garlic salt, pepper, onion powder. 6 hours on low. After shredding the pork to make the sauce I added four tablespoons each of brown mustard, black pepper grilling sauce. 6 ounces of tomato sauce to the BBQ sauce. I continued to cook, stirring occasionally, 2 hours longer on low.

text:
Definitely going to make this more often! Extremely easy to do. Don't cheap out on your bun though! Also once you pull it apart, the pork might get cold, so I put it in a separate pot and just leave it in the oven while I quickly broil the buns. The root beer you use will impact the flavour, so use your favorite brand (A&W for me), and just pick your favorite BBQ sauce. Don't pay attention to how much you use, as long as all the pork is covered.

I used a pork sirloin roast (it was on sale) and made it the day before.  The next day I mixed some BBQ sauce with liquid smoke  and hot sauce and stirred it into the pulled pork, heated it again in the slow cooker until the flavours blended.  I didn't want the pork to be too wet so I was careful with the amount of the BBQ mixture.  There end result was a success - everyone loved it.  I'll make this again.

Update : learned recently that "pork butt" and "pork shoulder" are the same cut of meat.

text:
This is ridiculously easy to make and tastes amazing. I ended up using a 4lb loin roast (it's what I had) and pouring a little over a liter of root beer over it to mostly cover it. Cooked on high for 3 hours then low for another hour or so, drained well and removed the bones, shredded the meat then added Sweet Baby Rays honey bbq sauce. Put it back in the crock pot on warm so people could serve themselves from there. You do not have to know anything about cooking to make this and get rave reviews.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3357067.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great and easy recipe. My Aussie husband loves the southern pulled pork that we get from home when we visit and he said this was the most authentic that I've made. I used two cans of A&W instead of one. I did rub salt, pepper, garlic powder, & onion powder on the meat, seared it, then put in slow cooker for six hours. Drained the root beer, pulled the meat off, which it really just fell off, and added the full bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce and put back on for another hour or so. Next time I think that I will add some liquid smoke and play around with the spices, but whether I do or don't, I think this will be my go to recipe from now on. Thank you for sharing such a wonderful recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I make it using a large "loin" roast, which is frequently on sale here, rather than the expensive, small and very lean tenderloin. It has a nice fat cap, and can be cut into sections that make it easy to fit in any size slow cooker. The fat gives the beneficial tenderness and flavor, without huge chunks that need to be removed, before or after cooking. Other than that, I season it then follow the recipe as written. It's easy, foolproof and always a huge hit.

text:
Loved it! So easy. I used chicken thighs because I'm not a big pork person, and then drizzled some worchestershire sauce over the top when I added the BBQ sauce. I also liked the chicken thighs because they cook faster and I was in a hurry since I didn't think ahead. It took about 2 hours on high, then drained the root beer, add the BBQ sauce then cook another hour. I had to shred the chicken myself a bit but it's so good I really didn't mind.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sometimes the simplest way is the best way! This is a no-frills recipe but it works great. While the obvious use for this dish is sandwiches, we've used it for several different dishes including shredded pork tacos. The other nice thing about this recipe is that you're free to use whatever barbecue sauce you want--our family is a big fan of Sweet Baby Ray's and we've used everything from the original recipe to honey barbecue to sweet and spicy. One modification that I strongly recommend is mixing your barbecue sauce in after you drain and shred the pork and letting it simmer on low for an hour. It makes a HUGE difference as far as imparting flavor to the meat.

Display Name:
col.trane

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm more of a Carolina bbq kind of guy, but the women in the family loved this due to the sweetness I assume. I used the pork tenderloin in an effort to cut out unnecessary fat. yes, not as good as using a Boston butt, but really not bad at all.   I cooked about 4 lbs of it. Rubbed with cracked peppercorn, sea salt, and granulated garlic. Covered with 2 liters of A&W (the only major brand of root beer worth anything). Added a few table spoons of hickory liquid smoke. cooked on low for 8 hours, reduced to warm for 4 hours. drained, pulled, and sauced with sweet baby rays hickory and brown sugar bbq sauce, added a couple more tablespoons of liquid smoke and cooked on high for about a half hour.  served on buns and topped with cole slaw. Pretty tasty. The liquid smoke is a must. Next time I'll use a bbq sauce that isn't quite as sweet. My wife and 3 year old daughter liked this so much that I'm sure we will make it regularly (assuming we don't get sick of it after eating leftovers for 4 or 5 days). I may try freezing some leftovers, if so I'll update this and let you know how it tasted after freezing. I freeze Carolina bbq all the time, I assume this will freeze ok too. Thanks for the recipe.

I love the fact that this recipe is so easy. I did not use a slow cooker, I used a pressure cooker instead. text:
This is so simple and tasty, with being a good starter recipe to make it your own!  I use a 2.5 Pork Loin Tips which our local store has on sale very often as a buy one get two free.  2.5 pounds is plenty for our family of 5.  But it was also great as a potluck offering.  The tips have less fat and when I can buy 7.5 pounds of meat for $12, I am pretty happy. I have used root beer, gingerale, rubbed the tips in McCormick's dry rubs, my home made rub, and it turns out wonderful everytime.

Display Name:
Ms Jean

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe! I used a small pork tenderloin from Trader Joe's which I butterflied (sliced in half) and sprinkled with salt, pepper and garlic powder and poked holes with a fork in the meat to help absorb the juices. I turned it occasionally in the root beer to make sure it cooked evenly. It was a small piece so when checking at 4 hours, the meat was coming apart very well. At that time, I drained it, reserving about 1 cup of the liquid. I returned the shredded meat, about 3/4 of a bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and the reserved liquid (for added moisture and flavor). I then cooked it for just over an hour longer. It came out wonderful! I recently had a pulled pork sandwich at a restaurant, and it was all dried out. Not this...it was very moist and delicious. Thanks Livie's Mammy!

text:
Easy, delicious and economical. Will make this again for a big crowd/ pot luck. I used a pork butt roast instead of tenderloin. It had more fat and was a traditional pulled pork consistency. I will try tenderloin to save on calories and cholesterol! I used Trader Joes Carolina BBQ sauce and retained a bit of the root beer sauce to balance out the vinegar taste. Great with cole slaw and baked beans. Next time I'll use up the collard greens to round it out. This is a keeper!

text:
Made this Saturday. I used the pork loin because we prefer a lean cut of meat. I put s&p as well as a little garlic powder on the pork before adding to the crock pot. I used A&W root beer. Cooked it the maximum amount of hours. I used Sweet Baby Rays spicy and sweet as well as a few shakes of hickory liquid smoke. I had large rolls, buttered them and grilled them until golden brown. This came out great. My husband enjoyed it very much. I tried a few shakes of hot sauce on mine it it was good. Had enough left over for 2 sandwiches. The next day I took a skillet and sprayed it and added the pork with a little more BBQ sauce. Tasted just as good as it did the first time. I will make this again but I'm also going to try a less sweet recipe as well. Good job Livie's Mammy!

text:
This is a very simple, no fuss recipe that tastes great!!  Except for using a cheaper cut of pork (Boston Butt shoulder cut) there is no need to take the extra steps to preseason or change a thing.  I have all boys and they devoured it!! Served with seasoned red potatoes & homemade coleslaw.  YUM YUM YUMMY!!

Easy & Delicious!!  First time ever making pulled pork.  I used a bottle of IBC Root beer.  Drained liquid after the meat was tender and easily shredded.  Put shredded meat back in crock pot with Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and let it simmer for another 2+hours.  Absolutely DELISH!  Definitely more of a sweet BBQ than savory.

text:
Made it for family's easter pot luck and everyone loved it. By far best bbq pulled prok recipe I ever ate and so easy!! Made with a 7lb pork shoulder roast and filled crock pot with root beer. I was skeptical of only using root beer as flavoring since I tend to use my whole spice shelf when cooking, but it is so yummy and not lacking in flavor. I cooked it overnight, drained, and shredded it. Put back in crockpot and added bbq sauce with a little water and cooked for another hour or so. Delicious!!

Listen up folks, this is it! I read some of the helpful reviews and this was my first time making this. I didn't add any seasoning or sear the meat or put any rub on it. Just a bottle of a&aw rootbeer and a 7lb pork shoulder instead of tenderloin (gotta lot of mouths to feed 'round here and tenderloin is expensive) but recipe is easy and spot on. Mine went in my Dutch oven cause I couldn't shove that big ol' swine in my crockpot! 325 for 4 hours in the oven and that was all that piggy said! I will definitely be adding this to the permanent recipe box.

text:
I was really hoping that this would be the best thing I have ever ate given >2,700 reviews. However, I just thought it was "okay". I used a pork butt as many suggested, used sweet baby ray's bbq sauce as many suggested, as well as A&W rootbeer. I've never made slow cooker pork before so wasn't sure what to expect. Husband said he thought it was good...it just seemed like it was missing something, perhaps the type of bbq sauce (sweet and spicey) wasn't a good selection. I will note that it did taste better the next day. My mom makes awsome pulled pork so I asked what she used to flavor it and she stated she actually used a combo of bbq sauce and she used Coke. So maybe it was the rootbeer that made it taste less than desirable....Will try it again using different bbq sauce to see it that will make a difference. The recipe was very easy to follow however so that is why I gave it 4 stars.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am not a fan of root beer, but I tried this recipe anyway because reviewers stated you could NOT taste the root beer, and the meat would be fall apart tender. I used a 4lb. pork tenderloin because that was what I had on hand, and it was very tender after about 8 hrs cooking on low. BUT, it definitely tasted of sweet root beer. So, I used a large bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's Sweet and spicy BBQ sauce. The spicy sauce did cut some of the sweetness. I don't know how you could say you can't taste the root beer. Next time, I will use beef broth as others did and not bother with root beer.

text:
This was just as incredible as all of the reviews said. I used whole foods brand root beer because it's made with real cane sugar and comes in a two liter bottle. I also used pork shoulder instead of tenderloin, although I found myself pulling out chunks of fat as I shredded the pork, because it was a fattier cut. I cooked about four and a half pounds of pork in two liters of root beer for seven hours, then I drained it and, also on the recommendation of other reviewers, added Sweet Baby Ray's Swwet and Spicy barbecue sauce. Some of the reviews had called for the Hot and Spicy, which, I discovered, no longer exists.

text:
Since I have never had pulled pork before, I have nothing to compare this to.  One thing I do know, this was tasty! tasty! tasty!  I only had 1 x 1-pound tenderloin so I used 1 cup root beer to which I mixed in about 1/4 cup of bbq sauce before pouring over the meat in the slowcooker.  I also added a little extra bbq sauce to the top of the tenderloin while cooking.  Even tho I reduced the amount of ingredients, I did not reduce the cooking time.  I served it with homemade mac and cheese--hubby& I absolutely LOVED it!  A definite make again recipe!!

text:
I did not care for this recipe. The root beer left an unappealing and strange taste on the meat, and I like root beer very much. It's almost a chemically strange twang that does not get covered up even under copious amounts of BBQ sauce.

The root beer did the job of cooking the pork and it actually smelled pretty decent while cooking.

Three others in the household seemed to either be meh about it, one liked it, which is why it gets 2 starts instead of 1. I will not make this again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6355314.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe very closely. I used a 2.5 lb. pork roast (on sale at Kroger; buy one, get one). I sprayed the crock pot with vegetable oil spray, placed it in the crock pot, set for 4 hrs. on high, poured Root Beer about halfway up the roast, poured a packet of McCormick's BBQ Pulled Pork Crock Pot Seasoning in the Root Beer and on top of the pork covering it heavily, covered, and waited. Two hours into it I flipped the roast to moisten some of the seasonings. When it was done,  I pulled it out, shredded on a cutting board, placed in a glass baking pan, mixed with 1 bottle of Kroger barbaque sauce and kept in the oven on warm until my dinner sides were finished (mashed potatoes and baked apples with cranberries). We ate the pulled pork both with and without a bun.

Display Name:
ClydesBonnie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe today using a boneless mini pork sirloin roast (2.25 pounds). This cut is not as lean as a tenderloin and not as fatty as butt. After seasoning the roast with black pepper and garlic powder. I slice two medium size onions and placed them in the bottom of my crock pot. Having read reviews which suggested the root beer made the pork too sweet, I added one tablespoon of Korean red pepper powder on top of the onions, placed the roast on top then adding the root beer. I am sure any hot pepper powder, flake or sauce would suffice. On the low setting the pork cooked in 9 hours. The pork was tender and flavorful with just a little heat in the background. I have made a similar recipe with gingerale but prefer the root beer.

text:
I am no whiz in the kitchen, but this was a simple to follow recipe. I don't blame anyone but myself, seeing as how I am not a big root beer fan in the first place. I thought that would tenderize the meat, not taste like hot root beer pork. It, to me, was not edible. Not only did it stink up the entire house like root beer, it did not taste well in the end. Again, I should have chosen a different recipe, so that is my fault. I would never make this again, or suggest it, unless you love root beer more than life itself.

userID:

Display Name:
GinaMiller
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easiest recipe by far!!  I used a 6.5 lb pork butt I got from my local butcher (not tenderloin), added root beer and a coating of bbq sauce (Sweet Baby Rays) and let it cook! I flipped it after about 5 hours of cooking. (Total cook time was 9 hours) Fell off the bone when it was done! I left it sit in a large bowl for about an hour to cool, then I shredded it. I put all of the juice from the cooker in a container and put aside. I then put the shredded pork back in the cooker and added the some (not all) of the leftover juice back in (to keep it from drying out) and put it on low/warm. It was even good without adding bbq sauce.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-07-06T08:43:55.327
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
31529
Display Name:
Auntylene
isPro:
False
followersCount:
31
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
228
favoritesCount:
1125
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6165542.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I needed pulled pork for lunch and so I started this the night before. I let the root beer and meat cook all night on low. In the morning I was a bit concerned because I wasn't sure it was done but I decided to drain the liquid and shred the pork. It shredded well and I put it back in the slow cooker with our favourite bbq sauce which is Sweet Baby Ray's. I let it cook on low for another couple hours until it was warmed through. This was absolutely delicious and it couldn't have been easier. I would recommend it and will definitely be making this again.
UPDATE: I use a pork butt roast for this and then when I shred it I pull out all the fat. This recipe is so versatile you can use almost any size of roast. I’ve used anywhere from a 3 lb to a 6 lb roast and they both worked fine. You just have to adjust the amount of bbq sauce you add at the end.

Used 1.25 lbs of meat so only cooked it for 5 1/2 hours, then 1 hour more with the sauce.  Amazing.

It was certainly easy enough to make. That ease is my favorite part of the recipe. I thought the meat was a bit too dry.  I also didn't think the flavor was exceptional. My husband also thought it on the dry side; he simply added more bar-b-q sauce to his.  I stacked my pork on a warm roll along with some cole slaw and with the added dressing from the slaw it was a good meal.  Just not as great as I expected it to be.  I will make it again but, perhaps next time, I'll use a different, more marbled cut of meat and more root beer.  That just might make it juicier.

text:
This was a a great recipe to make in advance and serve as my family arrived at different times (from out of town.)I took the advice on here and bought a Boston butt instead of a pork tenderloin- great advice, wonderful flavor. 
 I bought 2 (12 oz) bottles of regular Root Beer, and used about one and a half. I cooked it 6 hours in my slow cooker, let it cool, then shredded it and returned it to the slow cooker with BBQ sauce.
 
 It was a real hit--and we're a family that usually sticks to grilled chicken or fish! It's very easy, very tasty, and not $$$. So glad I found this recipe-I've shared it w/several friends and family who also love it!

This has become a regular dinner in our house.  We serve it on fresh yeast rolls and it is AMAZING.  The only reason I gave it four stars and not five, is that pork tenderloin does NOT make for good pulled pork.  User a cheaper cut of pork, like a pork butt/shoulder roast.  We have tried this with Dr. Pepper instead of root beer, and my husband likes that even better.  We ONLY use Stubb's BBQ sauce and it's perfect for this recipe.  We have made this several times and couldn't be happier with it, and it is SO EASY.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!!  This is fantastic and so easy.  I did not deviate from the recipe but I used a blade meat tenderizer on the pork loin and almost covered the pork with the root beer.  I let it sit overnight in the refrigerator.  In the morning I set the slow cooker for 6-1/2 hours on low, turning the meat over halfway through the cooking.  I drained it and didn't need 2 forks to shred, it was so tender it fell apart using a single fork!  I added a jar of BBQ sauce and set it back on low for about 45 minutes.  I have never ever had such tender pork!  It almost melted in my mouth!  I've  always smoked my pork when making pulled pork but after having this my smoker may gather dust!

country:

text:
I've made this recipe twice now and have enjoyed it both times, however the second time I think I left it in a little too long after adding the barbeque sauce and it started to get a little dry, but that was entirely my own fault. As per other reviews I used a 4lb pork shoulder both times as well as Sweet Baby Rays for the sauce and I have no complaints on either. The second time around I also poked the pork with a fork and rubbed it with salt, pepper and garlic powder before putting it in the crockpot and will continue to do it this way. Overall I really like this recipe because it is so simple and very yummy!

text:
This is a great simple recipe. I would go about 7 hours max. Much longer than that and it'll be too mushy, shorter and it'll be too difficult to shred. Don't cook the BBQ with the meat, just add it in 5-10 minutes before serving. It's much more flavorful that way.

text:
Yum! This was delicious, and root beer? Who knew? I made several batches of this for a camping-style family reunion and everyone loved it. The only thing is that the recipe calls for tenderloin. Really? That's kind of like taking a NY strip and cutting it up for stew. A little overkill and too tender to start. I used pork butt (shoulder) and by the end it was falling apart and so incredibly melt-in-your-mouth tender. Don't use tenderloin. I served on crusty rolls with provolone cheese and the sweet restaurant style slaw from this site. I also used Sweet Baby Ray's original sauce and will try our favorite, the honey-chipotle, next time. Perfect pairing and there were no leftover sandwiches. Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this with a 5lb pork loin (it was on sale) and did two bottles of beer instead of root beer. This was only because my husband hates root beer and I didn't want to have this huge pot of pulled pork that he wouldn't eat. I cooked it for 8ish hours on low with the beer, then drained it, pulled it and added the Bourbon Whiskey BBQ Sauce (made a double batch that the night before...is definitely better if you make it at least a day in advance and a double batch was just right for the amount of pork we had). It was a little too moist and had a relatively strong beer flavor, so we took it out of the slow cooker, added more BBQ sauce and finished it on the grill for 10-15 minutes. It got a great, smoky flavor and cooked off the excess liquid more effectively than the slow cooker could have. PERFECT! We will definitely make this again for family and friends. Great taste, very moist, really simple to make. LOVED THIS RECIPE!

text:
Amazingly easy. I used pork tenderloin (it was tender as all get out and flavorful... I hate pork butt b/c of all the fat & dark meat!), a salt/pepper/garlic powder rub. Then covered with root beer & followed directions. After 6 hours I took it out & shredded it, cleaned the crockpot and throw it back in with a sliced onion and some bacon and peppers (they were on hand). Also used Sticky Fingers Carolina BBQ sauce (Mustard based). Let it simmer for about an hour. AMAZINGGGG. Will make again soon.

text:
My husband didn't like this as much as I did because he likes smoked pulled pork, but I can't eat it, I don't like smoked meats at all. I really liked this. The only change I made was to use a shoulder instead of a tenderloin, and mix some BBQ sauce into my root beer. I doubled it, had to use two cans because my shoulder was so big and I wanted the meat swimming in the sauce. It turned out great. In fact I just ate a sandwich of it as cold leftovers. I'll make it again.

This was SO easy and a healthy alternative to the fatter pulled pork version. I used regular IBC rootbeer but I'll use diet next time since I don't think the sugar content actually matters for the tenderness of the meat. The pork pulled apart perfectly. The only thing I would say is that it's definitely more dry than traditional pulled pork, but the barbeque sauce help that! I will definitely make this again!

This recipe was great!

After my family made their yummy and approving noises while eating I informed them that I just slowed cooked the pork in root beer and then later added sweet baby rays honey bbq sauce. text:
Loved it, but we made a few changes. First I used a dry rub on a pork roast and place it over a bed of slivered onions and poured in half a 2L bottle of root beer to a large oval shaped slow cooker. Cooked on high for about 5 1/2 hours. When done I took the roast and onions out and shredded it into a bowl, added BBQ sauce and some of the left over juices and half a can of kernel corn. Served this concoction on cheese buns and put coleslaw on top. It was so good everybody cleaned their plates!

Made this this past weekend.  Put it in the slow cooker on Low at bedtime Friday, Saturday morning took it out (had to use a spoon as it fell off the bone) and shredded it. text:

Perhaps that was just too much for me.  I thought I enjoy the sweeter BBQ's but combined with the rootbeer, it may have been too much.  

Some wrote they used beer and maybe that combination would be better.

Next time, I'll try beer and maybe a sauce that isn't so sweet. It smelled good!

2443228
Display Name:
Teresa

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good and I would probably make it again with a few modifications.  I used a 4 lb boston butt instead and marinated overnight with a rub and rootbeer with chopped garlic and sweet onion.  Pulled directly from fridge to slowcooker and cooked on low for 8 hours.  The meat was so tender and there actually ended up being less waste than I thought using the butt.  I threw the shredded pork back in the pot and mixed in Sweet Baby Ray's sauce.  The thing that threw me off a little was tasting the pork without the sauce...the rootbear gave it an off taste that didn't quite do it for me.  The bbq sauce helped tremendously but I couldn't get the underlying taste out of my tastebuds to enjoy it the way I wanted to.  My family, however, devoured it and thought it was great.  Next time I might try coke or Dr. Pepper and maybe even just beef broth instead of the root beer.  I'm not a huge fan of root beer anyway so maybe that came through on this one.

UPDATE:  I have made this several times since writing the review and I do not marinate overnight.  I just throw everything in first thing in the morning.  Cut up a big onion, salt and pepper the boston butt (have done up to 5 1/2 lbs) and cover with half regular coke and half beef broth.  Amazing this way!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and tender pulled pork!

I rated it 4 stars because I did add a few ingredients I felt were absolutely necessary.

The day before I made a dry rub using salt, pepper, paprika, onion powder, and garlic powder.  I then placed the 4 lbs. of pork into a large container and marinated in root beer.  The next day I dumped the marinade out and placed the pork in the slow cooker.  I then added a bottle of root beer and cooked the pork for 8 hours on low.  After 8 hours the pork was tender and easy to pull apart.  I returned the pork to the slow cooker, added the BBQ sauce and cooked for about 45 min.  

It was amazing! Pair it with a delicious coleslaw! No leftovers guaranteed.

Good recipe, Im giving 4 stars because I had to doctor mine up a bit, or maybe I didnt buy a good BBQ sauce.  I love the idea of cooking in root beer!  And the cooked pork before sauce didnt taste like root beer.  I added a whole bottle of sauce and it wasnt enough flavor...was missing for sure.  I threw in some soy sauce, worstechire, mustard, tobasco sauce, garlic, white vinegar and salt.  Was great, my husband and his fantasy football draft friends loved it! Will make again!

text:
I also, like many others, believe that a tenderloin is not the right choice of meat for a slow cooker recipe. I used a pork roast. It was done in 4 hours and very nice and tender. I thought the root beer would be "the special ingredient" ... but in the end it didn't add much to the taste. When I pulled the pork, I reduced the root beer in a pan. Then added it to the meat and bbq sauce in the slow cooker. Taste was ok, not fantastic. I also added some chili paste to give it some pep, which turned out to be a good idea! I will try a different recipe next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cannot believe how great this recipe is!  I will be making this over and over.  My whole family just loved it.  I did make some changes, only because I have a family of seven and wasn't so sure there would be enough.  I used two cups or so of rootbeer.  It just didn't feel right to put meat on to cook without some kind of seasoning.  So I added a little onion salt, salt, and pepper and a smidge of garlic, just to taste.  Then I let it cook.  After about six hours I went ahead and pulled the pork, added the bbq sauce and dumped some  syrup on top stirred it up and let it cook another hour or so.  It was fantastic!  I recommed this recipe to anyone.  We served it on buns with a slice of onion and a few pickles....delish!

For those of you who said that the root beer didn't render any flavor to the meat, you must have used a cheap brand of root beer!!  I cooked an almost 7lb shoulder cut for 12 hrs on low and after I shredded it, I DIDN'T want to add the BBQ suace...the flavor was perfect without it.  I eventually added it to complete the recipe and it was still good.  I'm making this again tomorrow for my friend's 50th Birthday Party and this time I'm using a 10lber....I'm sure it will be a winner!!!

country:
None
text:
I will try the lesser expensive cut of pork next time. I always have used pork tenderloin, and after removing most of the outer silver skin, I cut it crosswise into pieces about 2 1/2" long. It's then a piece of cake to shred after cooking. I use a nice dark (real) beer, as well as sprinkle the pork with dark brown sugar, some dry mustard, apple cider vinegar, ketchup, and some hot sauce, which forms the basis of the BBQ sauce. Add more after it is cooked and shredded. Yum.

This was awesome!!! I normally don't go in and review recipes that I have tried but this one was such a hit with my family that I thought I should. I like to try the recipe just as it is without making any changes but in this case I didn't have quite the same ingredients so I had to improvise. text:
Excellent and easy. I do recommend using the pork tenderloin, however. We tried it with pork loin and just wasn't as tender or juicy. ALso after doing it a couple times with root beer, we decided that we didn't really like the residual root beer taste that much. So now we use cola, same amount. Also, single tenderloins that we get here don't weigh 2 pounds. They weigh a little over a pound. That works out well for my husband and me as well. Great recipe and concept!

text:
I usually make a more savory pulled pork recipe but wanted to try this because my niece doesn't like anything spicy.  I used Sprecher regular root beer and cut up a few Vidalia onions and a 1/2 tsp. liquid smoke and cooked on HIGH in the crock pot for 6 hours.  I drained it, shredded it, and returned it to crock pot and mixed it with lots of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce and a little of the leftover root beer liquid (that I boiled on the stovetop).  This was a very good recipe.  Definitely on the sweeter side but in NO WAY does this have an overwhelming root beer flavor like some other people are stating.

userID:
97051
Display Name:
2BCREATIVE
isPro:
False

6

madeRecipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I live in Australia where we don't have root beer. So, for my modifications I did as follows: Used a pork shoulder roast since it's a cheaper cut of meat and trimmed off much of the skin/fat that would have made the "crackling". Placed in crock pot fat side down and pour a can of Jim Beam & Coke over it (hey, it was all I had in the fridge). Cooked on low for 4 hours and then turned it and cooked for another 4 hours.  Removed the pork and pulled it apart on a cutting board. Actually, it just falls apart. Drain all juice before returning pork to crock pot and adding barbeque sauce and let it cook on low for another 45 minutes  to an hour.  The meat is soooo tender.

Easy and delicious.  Need I say more?  I was very sceptical because my other recipes are WAY more involved, but this one is the best so far.  I've shared it with a dozen friends and they are all amazed at how good it is.  Don't skimp on the tenderloin (but make sure it is plain - not previously seasoned or marinated).  When it goes on sale it is the same price as other cuts and it is FAR superior.  Try it.  You'll like it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness - this was SOOOO good and so easy!!  In fact, it was so easy, I didn't know how in the world it could possibly get the reviews that it did - but figured I had to give it a shot!  Like others, I was worried about the rootbeer and the taste it  might impart - something just didn't sound good about pork and rootbeer - but alas my worry was for naught.  This pulled pork was absolutely tender and delicious and could easily take on any restaurant.  I did add some chopped onion, garlic powder, salt and pepper - just to add some flavors that we like.  I cooked for 8 hours until it was falling apart, then took it out, drained the crockpot, shred the meat and put it back in and added Sweet Baby Rays original BBQ sauce.  I didn't measure out the sauce - just put in the amount that I thought looked right, and how we like it.  HIGHLY recommend trying this super easy but tastefully delicious recipe!!

text:
This meat is moist, tender, and delicious with no sauce or with any BBQ sauce.  I only had a small pork roast so added two large boneless skinless chicken breasts, chicken broth, water, and a couple of beef bouillon cubes.  Shredded them all together before adding generic sauce...delicious!

Made it again last night with a small pork tip sirloin roast (no chicken), water, bouillon cubes, and sprinkled with garlic powder, black pepper and parsley flakes.  Instead of shredding, I sliced it as a roast.  Again, very flavorful and moist...you cannot go wrong with this recipe.

Thank you, Livie's Mammy!

I took a tip from an earlier reviewer and also used Sweet Baby Ray Sauce. After I shredded I put it in a foil lined roaster pan, topped with sauce and mixed it up to get a good coat on all the meat, covered tightly with foil and baked at 350 for 45 minutes. I'd love to try this again. Next time I want to throw it onto a hot cast iron skillet and see if I can make a little "bark" ! YUM-

I personally feel that a pork butt or other pork roast is far too fatty w/gunk to pick out, Pork Loin is the way to go. 
We used to do this same thing when I was a Girl Scout leader years ago. Can be done w/a Cola as well. We used to do a big crock pot of ground beef, in a Coke, or a beef roast, torn up for Barbeque, its all GOOD! The easiest recipes in the world and they slurp it up w/great enthusiasm! Thanks for reminding me of this one, love it!

text:
Awesome!! I have made this twice in less than 2 weeks.  It is so easy and my family loves it! I cut the meat into 3 pieces so it is easier to pull apart. I remove all the meat after draining. Pull apart each piece and add back to the crockpot with the bbq sauce and a little water. Keep on warm until all has been pulled apart.

text:
I agree with MegaG, a cheaper cut of pork with suffice. I used a 2lb shoulder cut. The night before, I seasoned it with a bit of salt and pepper then stuffed it with a few pieces of garlic and onion.  Slow cooked it for 8 hours (while @ work), used Sweet Baby Rays Hot and Spicy sauce and dressed my poboy bun with horseradish mustard and my local deli's coleslaw. DELICIOUS! The horseradish really took it to the next level!

text:
This is what I did. The night before, I pulled a 4 lb pork shoulder out of my freezer, let it thaw, threw it into my slow cooker unseasoned and then emptied some Dr. Pepper over it (12 ounce bottle). I didn't have any root beer on hand. I didn't even bother with adding spices to it, didn't put salt, or a lick of seasoning on it beforehand. Why bother, it's going to get drowned in bbq sauce anyway and I was tired.   OMG, easiest dinner to make ever...and SO GOOD! Two thumbs up!

text:
Amazing recipe. I only tweaked a couple of things. For starters, I'm not a fan of tenderloin so I used boneless rib meat. Turned out wonderfully. The other thing I changed were the proportions. Seeing as I am not cooking for a whole family, I cut the recipe down to 1 lb of meat and used about 9-10 oz root beer. I then added barbecue sauce to taste. Definitely an amazing recipe, I'm going to be making this every time pork is on sale at the grocery.

This recipe was a BIG hit at our tailgate this past Friday!  The beauty of this receipe is that you can make as much as you like!  I use a 4lb pork shoulder roast and since it was so well cooked, it was easy to pull the fat off before placing it back in the slow cooker with the BQ sauce.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's sauce and made the Sweet Restaurant slaw to put on the sandwiches as one viewer suggested.  All gone!  The only downfall that night was we lost the game!  Thank you for sharing a GREAT tailgate recipe.  You can't go wrong!

text:
just cooked this today in my new crock pot, it was the first thing i ever cooked with it and it was a success! i was drawn to this recipe because you did not need a lot of ingredients, i used a pork loin because they did not have shoulders at the grocery store, i diced some onions, put it on the bottom of the slow cooker, i cut off some fat off the pork and sprinkled it with salt and pepper and then added the root beer, and slow cooked it for 7 hours on low, then i shredded it and added the bbq sauce on it and cooked it for another hour. i hosted my parents for dinner and they loved it and my husband couldn't get enough of it either. highly recommend!!

text:
Made this the first time exactly as the recipe states - it was really good.  Next time I added a layer of coarsly chopped onion on the bottom of the crockpot, put the roast in, salted it with Lawry's Season Salt and minced garlic, poured the rootbeer around it and let it cook for 10 hours on low.  It was so good we didn't even add the bar-b- sauce, just pulled it apart and ate it as a very tasty pork roast.  Both times I used a pork butt roast to make sure it wouldn't dry out with all that cooking.  Good recipe.  Love the novelty of the root beer!

text:
This is wonderful, and easy for the busy spouse or parent!!!  I do think it's better with 1 1/2-2 full bottles of BBQ sauce, but then again, I used a 6lb slab of pork shoulder, so perhaps there wasn't enough sauce to go around.  NOTE:  If you do use pork shoulder, cook it on low for 9 hours... the fat will melt off, and you won't get big chunks of it in your sami.  Also, the longer and slower it cooks, the more tender it is :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for a large party.  Bought 20 pounds of a cheaper pork cut and trimmed the fat.  Divided this between three crock pots and filled to the top with root beer (bought a couple two litre jugs - needed about one and one-half).  Put it in the slow cookers about 7:30AM, went to work, came home about 6PM. Drained root beer and allowed to cool slightly.  Shredded pork, added Sweet Baby Rays and put in the refrigerator.  Brought it back out a couple days later, back in the slow cookers (two now) and it was soooo goooood!  Everyone raved about the sandwiches.  Will use less BBQ sauce next time.  Will make again.
Review:

After comparing this so simple recipe to many other complicated multi-stepped ones, we decided to try it.  My 16 year old just ate three sandwiches and said it was "amazing" - after we cooked it - we strained the sauce, separated the fat, and cooked 1-2 down with equal parts store bought bbq sauce - then added meat and heated through.  Served with extra sauce and pickles.  Delish!

text:
The first time I made this, I was in labor with my baby.  It was almost done when we left for the hospital.  I tasted leftovers when I got home from the hospital and they were awesome!  We now make this about once every 2 weeks, and my husband and son fight over the leftovers.  I have used a couple different cuts of pork and they all work very well.  I use store brand root beer (a little more rb flavor than name brand), and Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce.  I recommend this recipe to everybody and will be adding it to my daughter and son's recipe boxes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/100877.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE:  Try Dr. Pepper & Chiles in Adobo, or Jalapenos if you like heat.  VERY GOOD!  Country Ribs work well too.  ORIGINAL REVIEW:  This... was... AWESOME!!!  I did marinate it over night in about a TB of cider vinegar and a rub of chipotle powder, onion powder, brown sugar and salt & pepper.  Used Virgil's (microbrewed) root beer, and needed 2 bottles to cover- I've had bad experiences with pork loin/slow cooker and not fully covering with liquid- After 3.5 hrs on low it was fully cooked so I proceeded with finishing the recipe and then left it on warm for another 3 hours til it was time to eat.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's Chipotle Honey, and it is quite good for a bottled sauce...  There's a bit of a kick to that one and that MADE it by perfectly balancing out the sweet.  Served on fresh Kaiser rolls with a broccoli/cabbage slaw and loaded baked potato salad with a lovely basil gin fizz my pro-bartender friend whipped up and it was a flippin' FANTASTIC meal- The PERFECT meal for having guests b/c everything was done when they arrived (house smelled GREAT!) and I was able to visit and not be busy in the kitchen other than merely slicing the rolls!  A TRUE KEEPER!!!  I would NEVER have thought of root beer, but it works!

I have to say this was good and I love root beer so I was excited to see how this would come out.  It definitely had a interesting flavor, but I found it a touch too sweet and I definitely could taste the root beer underneath.  The meat was moist and tender, but if I do make this again I will use a much lesser cut of pork.  Tenderloin is expensive and I feel I could of got more flavor from a roast then this had. There was just something lacking, maybe a more smokey flavor or something.  Could not put my finger on it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
oh my god i love this recipe! i couldnt believe how simple it was, for such a good dinner, it was a hit! i tweaked it a little...i added a little garlic powder, nutmeg and a little whiskey-also a little more rootbeer than the recipe calls for...also before draining the rootbeer broth i reserved some of the liquid in case it tasted/felt dry...as i was shredding the pork i would add a little of broth at a time! also i left some of the liquid in th bottom of the crock pot, (barely coating the bottom), and mixed that in...at this point taste it, mmm! yummy, then add your favorite bbq sauce, i used jack daniels honey brown sugar! i left it in the crock pot for just like 10 mins on warm, so the sauces can mingle. also i made some cole slaw to put on the bun with the pulled pork! so yummy!

text:
This ended up being just ok for us.  I didn't think the rootbeer added anything to the dish.  This could have just as easily been made with water or any other liquid for that matter, however the cooking style was great.  Slow cooking a pork roast (I used a roast, not a tenderloin) in liquid makes for amazing results.  Next time I'm going to use water and just season the meat with salt, pepper and some BBQ rub.  The BBQ sauce you choose will make all the difference.  Stick to one you like!

text:
This is AWESOME!!! I'm not sure what I like better the ease of making it or the wonderful flavor of it. I used a pork shoulder, rubbed it with salt, pepper, garlic & onion powder and brown sugar.  I added the rootbeer, cooked it in the slowcooker for 4 1/2 hours. I couldn't help myself from eating it while shredding it. It is very good at this point. It has a nice sweet flavor! I then cooked it about another hour with Sweet Baby Rays barbaque sauce. FANTASTIC!!!! For dinner, I paired this with garlic red skinned mashed potatoes and veggies. This freezes well so leftovers were frozen for lunches and what good lunches this makes!

text:
I used a boneless pork roast. Seansoned it with: salt, pepper, dill weed, basil and crushed minced garlic, added cut up onions, and mushrooms. Poured rootbeer on top of it, and cooked it on low for 8 hours. Shredded it, add bbq sauce, let warm up for an hour or so, and put it in "Kangeroo pita Pocket" Added a slice of cheese before heating it, added the meat and my husband loved it. Easy, simple and very good. Thank you for the idea.

text:
Absolutely exceptional.  I took reader's advice and rubbed it with salt, pepper and garlic powder and marinated in Dr. Pepper for about 8 hours on low.  The pork was so tender it was hard to get it out of the Crock Pot without falling apart.  Cooked it for another hour with the barbecue sauce.  Personally, I like to put some extra sauce on the bread (used hoagies) and ESPECIALLY some cole-slaw and a few sliced red onions on the sandwich.  If you havent tried it with the cole slaw, you're missing out.. the different textures and tastes really blend well together.  Outstanding!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is delicious and easy.  My pork tenderloin was about 2.5 pounds.  I used most of the 20 oz bottle of A&W rootbeer.  I cooked the pork for about 7 hours and poured out most of the juice before adding the BBQ sauce.  I kept a little of the juice (probably less than 1/3 cup).  Before I added the bbq sauce I added several dashes of Liquid Smoke-hickory flavor- to the pork.  Then I smothered the pork in homemade BBQ sauce (inspiration courtesy of the Neely's). I modified their recipe by adding some Liquid Smoke and honey and cutting out most of the sugar and scaling down the vinegar a bit. I made the pork sandwiches carolina style with coleslaw.  I also prepared some crispy onion rings to top the pork. Everything turned out really well.  I will definitely make this again!!!!

text:
Lip smacking and couldn't be easier!  My store had 2.5 lb. packages of country-style ribs on sale, so I used those instead of the tenderloin.  I seasoned the meat with 2 tablespoons Williams-Sonoma Coffee & Spice Rub and used A & W root beer and KC Masterpiece Original barbecue sauce.  There was quite a bit of broth and fat that had to be drained off before saucing the meat.  Perfect with potato salad and Texas Caviar (spicy, marinated black-eyed pea salad).

userID:
3843564
Display Name:
sgolsen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe produces super tender pork.  The meat doesn't really seem to have a root beer flavor to it at the end but it definitely keeps the meat moist throughout the cooking process and it ends up just right.  The hardest part of this recipe is waiting for the meat to finish.  I've cooked it twice now and each time I find myself pulling little bits of the meat off when no one is looking because I just can't wait.    I took the advice of most of the reviewers and skipped the tenderloin in favor of a pork shoulder which I think was definitely the way to go.  A tenderloin just doesn't have the fat (read: flavor) to make proper bbq.  I find that the recipe really hinges on the bbq sauce you use.  The first time we used Picky Vicky Brazenly Bold sauce and it was the perfect combination of heat and spice.  Unfortunately it isn't easy to come by so the second time we split the meat up and tried a few different sauces and though the meat was just right it didn't quite knock my socks off like it did with the Picky Vicky sauce so for this recipe to really shine you need to know your sauce before you start cooking.
Review:
Rating:
5

This was SO easy!! I did do it a little different.  I rubbed the meat (all 17 pounds) down with organic garlic, salt, sugar, and pepper, drizzled oil and sherry vinager on it and let it set in the frig for 7 hours. Then I baked it in the oven at 200'F for an hour before turning the temp down to 170'F.  I served this for my family's Christmas (all 38 of us) and it was SO good!!

As per other reviewers I sprayed my crock-pot with Pam and it was no problem to clean up afterward.  Thanks for sharing this wonderful recipe, I'll definately make it again this winter.

text:
The first and most approved recipe suggests not using pork tenderloin, but if you're health-conscious at all I would stick to the recipe. It's true that other cuts of pork are cheaper, but they are also packed with fat and calories. Pork tenderloin is one of the leanest cuts, so I don't mind paying a little extra. This recipe is fantastic, all I add is garlic salt and pepper, and I cook it with Sweet Baby Ray's for an additional hour after I shred it. I've probably made this twenty times!

text:
My Husband and I made these to take for the Wednesday night before Thanksgiving dinner. I wanted to do something for my parents and give them the night off so i cooked a Pork Shoulder roast in Coke all day Tuesday (6am to 9pm). Drained it and took all of the fat out and put it in a container. Wednesday night I put it in a slow cooker with some BBQ sauce and a little vinegar and made the best sandwiches ever. My whole family loved them and even ate some for breakfast and lunch the next day. No leftovers. Will definitely make these again. Marinating in the soda makes all the difference

text:
I loved the root beer as the marinade!!  I used a 4.5 lb boneless pork shoulder and 6 hours on low heat was not enough time.  I ended up pulling the pork apart by hand because it was so tough... Once it was all pulled, I put it back in the slow cooker with 2 bottles of bbq sauce and turned the temp up to high for 1 hour... it came out AMAZING!!!!  Next time I'm cooking for a big crowd I'll allow at least 8 hours for the pork to get soft.

country:

text:
This definitely gets extra stars for ease, except for cleaning the caramelized tonic (pop/soda/whatever) out of my crock pot, of course!  I bought a shoulder instead of the tenderloin and did a light rub of Cajun spices before hand, though I don't think it needed it and wouldn't bother next time.  I flipped the knob to low and took a nap but when I got up I realized I hadn't plugged in the cooker!  I cranked it up to high for a few hours to compensate.  It was a bit of a struggle getting the meat off the bone -- don't know if that was due to the high heat or what -- but it was definitely tender.  After draining the root beer and fat I had to hand-shred the meat and then mixed it in with some very spicy BBQ sauce (Stubbs Spicy) and added a splash more root beer to mellow the heat.  Served it with tart slaw and a sweet baked beans and it was very good.  I'll be making this again soon for a football party but will use a boneless shoulder if I can find it, won't bother with the rub, and will use the proper setting.  The sauce you chose really makes this recipe, I think.  The tonic just keeps the meat nice and moist while cooking.  Thanks for a super-easy recipe!

I made this for a Halloween party that we attended this year.  Everyone was bringing soups and food that could sit in a crock pot and be served whenever everyone felt like eating.  I decided to bring this, so that we had something a little more substantial.  Everyone LOVED this pulled pork!  I used pork shoulder, rubbed it in garlic, salt and pepper and browned it prior to putting it in the crock-pot.  I made two whole roasts, so the cooking time was much longer, and after we pulled the meat we just put it back in the crock and skipped the oven step.  I have made it twice since then, and I have people calling me for the recipe!

text:
Yum!  The pork just fell right apart.  It tasted great.  I didn't have to fuss with it.  I added just a dash of liquid smoke to the pot, but I don't know that it made any difference.  I used our favorite barbecue sauce, I only used just enough of it, you don't want the pork swimming in BBQ sauce.  Then I let that sit on low for another hour or so.  Then you put a little BBQ sauce on the bun, spoon the pork onto it, and YUM! The pork was super juicy and tender.  We'll definitely have this again.  We used pork tenderloin because it was on sale for a really good deal.  I might also try this with another cut of pork, or maybe pork chops without the BBQ sauce.  Anyway, the rootbeer + pork idea works great.

This was soooo easy.  I used a 5lb boneless pork butt; cooked it overnight for 10 hours; shredded it and mixed in BBQ sauce (but did not use the whole bottle) and reheated it in the slow cooker 2 hours before serving.  Served it with Mom's Cole Slaw from this site.  Great meal.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/812736.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, this is seriously the best pulled pork I have had. I used Pork spareribs, instead of tenderloin, layered 11lbs of it into my slow cooker, seasoning each layer with salt, pepper, and A&W Root beer. I started the Nesco at 3PM and let it cook throughout the night, and at 7AM the next morning, I shredded it and added sweet babyrays. I then let it cook for about an hour more, letting the flavors really meld together. My husband took it to his work, where they ate it on wheat hamburger buns, and when everyone asked me what I did, when I responded rootbeer, they were very surprised. A very good recipe. One thing I would recommend is to watch the liquid content, because as the meat cooks, it releases liquid, and when I opened my Nesco this morning, it was to the rim with liquid, almost overflowing. :) Sooooooo good.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/243658.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a pressure cooker and would highly recommend it if you are bent for time or want to speed the process up. I started off with putting a dry rub and letting it sit overnight. I used spareribs because its what we already had in the freezer and used a bottle of beer instead of rootbeer. I cooked it in the pressure cooker for about an hour on low heat. It came out tender and juicy. Then stuck it in the oven with some Sweet Baby Ray's!  FYI - I definitely won't be using spareribs again because getting all the fat off was a huge hassle. And I don't think I will use beer next time. It gave such a foul odor when it was cooking and you could faintly taste it in the meat. Weird taste. I'll probably try broth and see how that goes. Overall, everyone really enjoyed it~

text:
I used country style pork ribs because they were on sale and I bought a family size package for under $6.00. I cut the meat away from bone and some of the fat off before throwing in crock pot with rootbeer. Drained liquid, shredded and added a bottle of bbq sauce.  This has got to be one of the easiest, cheapest and best tasting recipes around.  Just threw some on hamburger buns with thinly sliced onion and pickles.

Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good pulled pork!!! Made this for my bf & I this past wk. I had to zoom off to a networking event (I am "in transition" as they call it...). I went to McD's w/ my friend & my bf had this for dinner! I just made a sandwich w/ the leftovers & wish I would have had this hot out of the crock pot instead of a cheap fish-o fillet sandwich & fries (hehe!)!!! I ended up mod. this a bit to suit my/our tastes. Here's what I did: a) rubbed tenderloins (purchased (2) 1 lb. tenderloins on sale for $2.50 ea.!!!) w/ 2 T dried minced garlic & b) sliced a med. onion & added it to the sc w/ the pork. B/c I had to leave b4 everything was done cooking (cooked on low for 6.5 hrs.), I had my bf drain/shred the pork & add the BBQ sauce (we used a bottle of generic brand hickory flavored sauce that I wanted to clear out of my fridge) when he got home. Next time, I'd like to add BBQ sauce about 1 - 1.5 hrs. b4 the cooking time is up so that the flavor permeates thruout the meat & the sauce thickens a bit (I'd also like to try mix. sauces like Nandabear did). One thing to note: If you do not care for RB, do not worry. The taste is nonexistent (IMHO). You could easily sub. any dk. colored carbonated bev. w/ great results - try Dr. Pepper! You can also use pork butt/shoulder instead of tenderloin if you are on a budget (tenderloin tends to be more expensive). Served on onion rolls w/ bread & butter pickles, kettle chips & the rest of the RB to wash it all down! Tx. Livie's Mammy :)

text:
Excellent and EASY!  I put a 3 lb. boneless pork shoulder in the slow cooker, covered 3/4 of the way in root beer, and cooked overnight (from about 11PM to 6AM).  Woke up, drained the juiced and rootbeer, and the pork shreeded apart with ease!  Added some nice bbq sauce to it and it was delicious!  I kept "taste testing" it at 6:30 in the morning it was so good!  Thanks!

Turned out real well.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!! I did not use the root beer because I didn't want it too sweet, was looking for middle of the road because I was having a little party of five of neighbors & didn't want too sweet or too spicy so I used pork sirloin rib end roast 4.17 lb.(butcher's recommendation) with 1 cup of water.  I put it in the slow cooker, high for two hours, low for five hours, pulled the pork (super easy with a fork - I am a total novice), drained and put the meat back in the slow cooker with two bottles Bullseye original barbecue sauce.  I served it on potato rolls (central PA) with cole slaw & everyone loved it.  I'm very happy since this is the first time I've tried pulled pork.  I will most definitely make again!
